title: Hard partying Malia Obama celebrates 20th birthday Montauk
story: Photos obtained exclusively by DailyMail.com show Malia Obama partying at the Montauk hot spot, Surf Lodge, as she celebrated her 20th birthday on Saturday afternoonShe said the group arrived on Saturday afternoon and stayed for about an hour while smoking cigarettes and 'partying'.'At one point she was just standing in a bikini,' the insider said. 'She wasn't in a good state, I can tell you that.'The insider added that it appeared as though no one in Malia's group was drinking alcohol.Photos show wine glasses on tables near Malia at the restaurant, though the one closest to her was empty and a bottle of coconut water sat beside it. Other nearby glasses were filled with a pinkish clear liquid.In one image, Malia can be eating a snack, which looks like it could be a bagel with lox.A short video clip of the party obtained by DailyMail.com shows Malia grooving to the music as she sits with a group of friends - both men and women - who appear to be her age.Surf Lodge is a favorite of the former first daughter, who was spotted there last year as well when she celebrated her birthday.           An insider told DailyMail.com that it appeared as though no one in Malia's group was drinking alcohol. Photos show wine glasses on tables near Malia at the restaurant, though the one closest to her was empty and a bottle of coconut water sat beside it          Malia wore a T-shirt, white patterned bikini bottoms and sneakers as she partied at the beach club with friendsOne insider told Page Six that Malia knew staff members' names as she partied at the club on Saturday. The Surf Lodge is a famed celebrity haunt, with First Daughter Tiffany Trump partying at the club alongside Joe Biden's granddaughter Naomi last month.The 24-year-old first daughter was also joined by her other socialite friends, including Andrew Warren, Peter Brant Jr., Alex Assouline, and Jesse Bongiovi .Over the same weekend that Malia Obama making a visit to the venue, Christie Brinkley made an appearance to celebrate her wine brand, Bellissima.The Surf Lodge, a restaurant and hotel, offers live musical acts throughout the summer, with acts including Jessie J, Janelle Monae, Jaden Smith and Lupe Fiasco performing this summer.Over the last decade, the venue has faced a number of noise and zoning violations, and was even forced to temporarily stop its live music program in 2016 over the charges.Back in 2012, it was forced to pay a record-setting $100,000 fine to East Hampton over hundreds of violations.That same year, the venue was bought by Montauk Properties, who at the time said it didn't 'expect to have any of these type of issues going forward'. Braving the heat on summer break! title: Adorable moment chimpanzee reunited foster parents
story: Limbani was seen drinking through a straw when he hears someone call his name from behind (left) and sees it is his foster parent Jorge (right)The chimp makes sure that his arms are wrapped tightly around the man's neck and his legs around his waist during the loving embrace.Limbani is then quickly distracted after seeing Jorge's wife, Tania, walk into the room. He lets out another excited sound before reaching out to her and giving her a cuddle.The heart-warming footage was posted on Instagram by the Zoological Wildlife Foundation in Miami, who say the couple helped provide the animal with 'around the clock care for the first few months of his life'.Limbani is now staying at the zoo, but regularly sees the couple who raised him when they visit. And even though there can be months between visits, the foundation said the Limbani's reaction is 'always the same' when he is reunited with them.Limbani was rejected after he was born with pneumonia and rejected by his mother.  Limbani could not hide his excitement as he gives Jorge a hug (left). Limbani hit headlines in January when a video of him with a Mastiff dog, named Bruno cuddling went viral.Another video on the Zoo's website shows 'bundle of love' Limbani playing with a golden Tabby tiger cub.

title: Footage shows undertaking Mercedes driver swerving traffic
story: Peter Goodfellow, 36, was jailed for 11 months after the horrifying crash which sent the Mini spinning across three lanes          Video shows Goodfellow undertaking other vehicles as he whizzes down the motorway at dangerous speed.          These dramatic dash-cam images show the moment a speed maniac weaves in and out of motorway traffic at upwards of 100mph, before colliding into a mini at top speedHe was also found to have two bald tyres on his white Mercedes C250 vehicle at the time of the incident on July 19 last year.The smash happened on the M4 carriageway westbound, at the Leigh Delamere services near Chippenham.Goodfellow, of Swindon, Wiltshire, was sentenced at Swindon Crown Court last Friday to 11 months behind bars.Terrifying moment a baby in a buggy rolls off the pavement...Dramatic moment driver, 57, attempts to flee traffic stop...Share this articleHe was also disqualified from driving for 29 months, after which time he will need to retake his driving test. He must pay a victim surcharge of £140.The female driver of the Mini suffered minor injuries.PC Will Ayres, of Wiltshire Police Roads Policing Unit, said: 'Dash cam footage was invaluable in securing this conviction against Goodfellow.          The car hits the mini at top speed and sends it spinning across three lanes of traffic          eter Goodfellow, aged 36 years, was arrested after police arrived at the scene and requested dash-cam footage from nearby cars whose drivers had seen the incident'He is a dangerous driver who had no regard for other road users. This was a busy time of day on a busy stretch of the M4.'Goodfellow put other road users lives at risk, not just by driving at excess speed, but also undertaking vehicles which led to a collision and left an innocent driver with injuries.'Thankfully, these injuries were minor although the incident has no doubt really affected her.'Looking at the dash cam footage provided by a witness, it is so lucky that nobody was more seriously injured.'           The dangerous white Mercedes pictured moments before the incident          The driver of the white Mercedes C250 was also found to have to bald tyres on his car, meaning the grip on the wheels had been excessively worn down, making an accident much more likely

title: Meet BRAVEST football fans England Ramos family cheering Colombia tonight
story: The Ramos family's Colombia flag sticks out in a sea of red and white St George's flags on the Kirby Estate in Bermondsey, south-east London          Sandra Ramos, right, will be cheering on Colombia along with her sons Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and Kevin Jhonnes, 18, daughter Alejandra Ramos, 29, granddaughter Adeline, seven months and her American bulldog Troy, three, when they take on England in tonight's big matchFlagging an interest! Football fan who covered his estate in...Share this articleHer eldest son Jean-Paul Jhonnes echoes his mother's passion and he too is hoping that Colombia will win.'I was born here in England and London is my home but I am only supporting Colombia. They are my team. I don't know how it's going to go. It'll be very close, a difficult game.'The England supporters think it will be easy for them, but I don't think it will. Colombia are in a strong position and all the top teams are out. It's been a very unpredictable World Cup.'Jean-Paul, 19, who is currently training at a football academy dreams of making it as a professional player, says despite the rivalry there is a great community spirit on the Kirby Estate, in Bermondsey, south-east London.'Our neighbours are very nice. Most of them will be supporting England but it doesn't matter. They have invited us to watch the match with them on a projector downstairs.'We have invited family and friends to join us so hopefully we will be able to make ourselves heard.'We will be dancing the salsa and the bachata when Colombia score!  Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and his mother Mother Sandra Ramos, 48, will be cheering on Colombia from their second floor flat tonight while all of their neighbours support the Three Lions'It is a very important game. It feels like it is a semi-final match. Whoever wins tonight – Colombia or England – has a good chance to make the final.'Cheering on Colombia will be mother Sandra, 48, her sons Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and Kevin Jhonnes, 18, her daughter Alejandra Ramos, 29, her granddaughter Adeline, seven months and her American bulldog Troy, three. Sandra added: 'There is a real community spirit here on the estate. My neighbours are very friendly.'A post-war housing development the heart of Bermondsey, the Kirby Estate has become an a tourist attraction after proud residents strung up 300 St George's flags – and a couple of Colombia tricolours – to mark the 2018 World Cup.School groups and foreign tourists are now flocking to the four-storey blocks to take in the sea of England flags.'There is a real community spirit here on the Kirby Estate,' Chris Dowse, 39, one of the organisers, told MailOnline.'We put letters through everyone's door saying we were going to put England flags on the balconies. Everyone was up for it.'And there are a few other flags as well – Colombian, Brazilian – and that's fine.'People say there's no communities left in London but there absolutely is.'We have people here from lots of different communities, lots of different backgrounds.'We wanted to have a barbecue to celebrate the estate so we put letters through all the doors. I never expected such a response.'I've been properly overwhelmed and humbled by how much everyone's come together.  Everyone on the Kirby Estate tonight will be huddled around a big screen cheering on the Three Lions besides the Ramos family who will be going for Colombia'I grew up in the 80s, back then it was exactly like this, all about the community.'The estate is old fashioned, it's just the way we are. Bermondsey people are known for it.'We've had school kids and tourists come and have a look at all the flags. It's mad.'I want people to come tonight to watch the match. Someone's going be happy and someone's going to be sad but it will be a great night.'

title: Animal outcasts sanctuary Britains wonderfully eccentric farm
story: No room in the barn for this nativity star: For the first few months of his life, Dougal was bottle-fed by members of the public at a farm park in their nativity scene. When he outgrew that and was being sent for slaughter, Manor Farm stepped in. ‘He’s a rascal,’ says Di. ‘Having been given lots of attention, he feels it’s his right to demand fuss from visitors, who are taken by surprise when he head-butts the back of their knees!’          Bullied pig called Simon: Partially-sighted and with deformed front legs, Simon was so terribly bullied by the bigger pigs he shared a sty with at another rescue centre that they asked Manor Farm to take him. ‘He was grossly overweight which didn’t help with his movement problems — if he was a human it’s like he’s walking on his wrists,’ says Di. ‘He’s now lost weight and is enjoying life with his friend Brooke. She chivvies him around all day and I give him strawberries and melon which he loves.’          Jack the VERY stroppy Donkey: Jack was the first non-hen to be taken in by Manor Farm rescue sanctuary after it came into being about seven years ago. ‘We bought the land for it with some money left to me by my Uncle Jack,’ says Di, ‘so when a donkey sanctuary asked me to look after a donkey called Jack it seemed meant to be. The only thing is — he’s nothing like my Uncle Jack who was very gentle whereas donkey Jack is quite stroppy!’Less than a decade ago, Di and Alan were both running businesses from their Nottinghamshire village home.Now they’re also running an animal sanctuary that currently cares for more than 100 farmyard creatures. And not just any creatures. They take in the ones no one else wanted, rejected because they were disabled, had health problems, special needs or simply grew too old.Or, in the case of the many rescued from petting zoos, simply because they grew up. ‘People imagine these animals are living a lovely life in the petting zoo until they die naturally,’ says Di, ‘but that’s not so in the majority of cases.Adorable moment Limbani the chimpanzee shrieks with joy and...Fury at female Kentucky hunter who posted sickening photos...Share this article‘Lambs can be bred out of season to be Christmas attractions to be bottle-fed by visitors but once they’ve grown out of the cute stage, they go into the food chain.’What’s more, they often come to her emaciated, neglected and infested with parasites. Then the battle is on to save their lives. That battle costs Manor Farm Charitable Trust up to £100,000 a year — around a fifth of which are vets’ bills.‘Our vets are constantly challenged by the ageing of our animals,’ Di admits.No wonder — it’s rare farmyard creatures live more than a year or two before going to be slaughtered.          Blind Stevie's a littler wonder: When blind Stevie the Mallard duck came to Manor Farm, they knew he needed a friend to guide him round. ‘I chose a girl called Wanda,’ says Di, ‘because female ducks are louder than the boys and I believed he needed someone noisy to follow around.’ Stevie was found with big scabs over his eyes. ‘We didn’t know at first if he’d been attacked, if they were infected or even if he had eyes. He did — but he was blind.’ Now Wanda’s his guide duck.          Toothless OAP fed on a banana: Life’s left Dolly so scared of human strangers that when summer comes Di can’t call in a shearer —instead she has to do it herself with nail scissors. Dolly, a breeding nanny at a farm park, came to Manor Farm in 2012 when they started neglecting her because she’d become barren. ‘She barely had the strength to hold her head up,’ says Di. ‘But she had an indomitable spirit we could all do with.’ Dolly, who has no teeth, was fattened up with mashed banana and is now in the equivalent of her 90s.          Stumble, duck who live up to his name: Stumble may only have one leg but he’s still the scourge of the female ducks he shares his enclosure with. ‘He’s perfected the ability to jump on to a mate,’ says Di. ‘They all run but they can’t hide from him. Stumble’s leg had to be amputated after getting caught in fishing wire. He’s had a difficult summer because he’s moulted and lost his tail feather and wing tips — which help keep him stable. So he keeps falling over.’ And falling in love.          Goat that costs £3,000 to perk up: Of all the Manor Farm animals, Jo cost the most. So thin when Di rescued him from a petting zoo that he couldn’t hold his neck up, she nursed him back to health in her kitchen. ‘He came up to me as if to say “help me,” ’ she says. Jo was covered in lice and had digestive problems. ‘We nearly lost him several times — he was always the one needing the vet at midnight,’ says Di. But she doesn’t begrudge a penny of the £3,000 he cost. ‘He’s the sweetest creature,’ she says.But it’s not just the vets who have been learning. Di has too. ‘In 2010 I treated myself to four hens as a reward for completing an MA in creative writing and I found it was a slippery slope ,’ she says.A year later, a relative died, leaving her money to buy the six-acre field behind the house. Slowly the brood grew and the dozen or so enclosures now house 64 hens, 27 goats, two donkeys, one pony, two pigs and 30 sheep.Di now employs a full-time member of staff and three part-timers. Every day begins at 6am when she gets the feed ready. It ends at 10.30pm — earlier in winter — when she puts the animals to bed. She also finds time to run her publishing business (and Alan his marketing consultancy firm) which help bankroll Manor Farm.          Ewe with a stiff neck: Born with a twisted neck, Hilda was too deformed to breed and too skinny to slaughter so Di took the tiny ewe in. 'We were told she'd never take to humans,' she eat out of a trough because she'd never seen them before. But within a month she was letting us touch her and gradually she got a lust for life. Now she loves to be cuddled and her tail wags madly like a big dog          A goat the size of a pony: Ronnie, the Anglo Nubian goat, is the size of a Shetland pony. ‘They’re a large breed but he’s a particular giant,’ says Di, ‘and that’s how he ended up here — his elderly owner couldn’t cope with the size of him and was going to have him shot.’ So she did a 135-mile round trip to save him. ‘I knew he was big but even so it was a bit of a shock when I saw him.’Other money comes from corporate and personal donations and the sale of eggs and wool from the animals online. Apart from cash worries, there are other downsides. ‘I’ve had every injury known to man — I’ve lost a nail to a goat horn, been electrocuted by a fence and accidentally injected myself with goat antibiotics,’ says Di.But this pales into insignificance compared to the pain of losing one of their beloved creatures. The sanctuary is full so it’s only with the death of an animal that another can be saved. They come from farm parks, via social media or from other rescue centres.‘It is hard work,’ says Di, ‘but when you see the sheep feeding on the grass and the goats happy in their enclosure, it’s worth it.’          Hen healed in a roasting tray: Buffy the ex-battery hen was doing perfectly well at Manor Farm when she was sat on by another bird and left with a bruised back last winter. ‘One of my biggest joys was that we got Buffy back to health with daily physio,’ says Di. ‘Although I do feel a bit guilty that we kept her in a roasting tray so she could rest her neck on the edge of it. She’s still a bit stiff and walks with a bit of a goose step but is otherwise fine. And she now loves cuddles — every time you pass her she wants you to pick her up.’          Sheep who need a dentist: Dumpy is easy to spot: his teeth have grown so big, his jaw is deformed. ‘But you really couldn’t meet a sweeter sheep,’ says Di. She saved him from the slaughterhouse last year — he was on a trailer bound for it when the farmer’s daughter put out a social media appeal. ‘We all clubbed together to buy him and the farmer said we could have him — as long as we gave the money to Comic Relief,’ says Di. But those teeth keep the dentist busy.Manor Farm Charitable Trust | Lifelong sanctuary for livestock in need

title: World Cup WAG thinks her
story: Flying the flag: England striker Jamie Vardy's wife RebekahHer sharp-shooting husband could fire England into the World Cup quarter-finals tonight.But as the nation holds its breath, striker Jamie Vardy's wife Rebekah is hogging as much of the limelight as she can – claiming her husband's success is partly down to her.The 36-year-old reality TV star has been doing media interviews almost daily while in Russia with her family.She has also been sharing pictures online of her time with other WAGs, boarding private jets and going on extravagant shopping trips, as well as the inevitable glamorous matchday selfies.Estimates suggest 20million people will watch the game on TV in Britain tonight and 36million pints of beer are expected to be drunk across the country today – 17million in pubs and 19million at home.The British Beer and Pub Association also predicted £25million would be spent on food in pubs today and £30million on meals eaten at home.Meanwhile, the National Grid expects electricity demand to spike by 700 megawatts at half-time – equivalent to 27million fridge doors opening at the same time as fans grab another beer.The grid's director of system operations Duncan Burt said: 'We'll balance supply and demand second by second in real time.'Rebekah Vardy (pictured at England's game against Belgium, left, and on social media, right) has been doing media interviews almost daily while in Russia with her family and sharing pictures online England face Colombia at 7pm in the 45,000-seater Spartak Stadium in Moscow, with around 4,000 of their fans thought to have travelled to Russia. Mrs Vardy will be there too of course, cheering the team – and herself – on.She claimed yesterday the national side had prospered thanks to the presence of their loved ones.Kim Kardashian proves she IS a Beyonce fan as she bops along...Love Island: Megan cements viewers' opinions that she is a...Love Island: Georgia is left RAGING as Josh re-couples with...Adorable moment Limbani the chimpanzee shrieks with joy and...Share this articleShe said coach Gareth Southgate has helped get the most out of the players by allowing them time alone with their families and friends, unlike during previous tournaments.She told The Sun: 'He's got the right idea of the team mentality. He's really relaxed with the players and he makes an effort with all of the families.'He really encourages family days after games, which relaxes the players – it brings a bit of normality in'.

title: Gay cure therapy outlawed
story: Victim: Dean had two so-called exorcisms before accepting his homosexualityThe Government's LGBT (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender) action plan – backed by £4.5million from Whitehall – also promises to hold a consultation on making it easier for people to legally change their sex.Ministers originally promised to allow adults to change their gender legally without a doctor's approval last year, but the plan has been repeatedly delayed amid growing criticism.BBC chief stunned as secret staff sex survey reveals 417 of...Eddie Mair hits back at reports he left the BBC after...Share this articleLast night Prime Minister Theresa May said: 'We can be proud that the UK is a world leader in advancing LGBT rights, but the overwhelming response to our survey has shone a light on the many areas where we can improve the lives of LGBT people.'I was struck by just how many respondents said they cannot be open about their sexual orientation or avoid holding hands with their partner in public for fear of a negative reaction.'No one should ever have to hide who they are or who they love. This LGBT action plan will set out concrete steps to deliver real and lasting change across society, from health and education to tackling discrimination and addressing the burning injustices that LGBT people face.'The action plan said the Government will consider 'all legislative and non-legislative options' to prohibit 'promoting, offering or conducting conversion therapy'.It said: 'We will act so that LGBT people feel safe in their own homes and in their communities. Our survey shows that many LGBT people do not report hate incidents they experience and that the abhorrent practice of conversion therapy is still alive in our country.

title: Anything bear ter Bouncing bear copies kids enjoying playtime St Louis Zoo

title: England fans shake nerves rally Three Lions
story: England fans have another reason to hope tonight's game against Colombia doesn't go to penalties, as it would mean an overlap with ITV2 reality TV show Love IslandBut with tensions rising as the minutes tick down, hundreds have taken to Twitter to discuss the familiar England cocktail of expectation, doom, gloom and optimism - with one hilariously asking whether 'nerves' were enough reason to call in sick.    Fans have already endured a roller coaster ride of emotions having gone from apathy to elation and then disappointment as England's World Cup has progressed - but a victory over Colombia would see a tidal wave of excitement sweep the nation as the draw opens up extremely favourably for England. Expectations had been low for the squad following more than a decade of tournament failure, but a barnstorming win over minnows Panama wowed fans and commentators alike - as the nation's new golden boy Harry Kane netted himself three goals on the way to a 6-1 route. 'Rake thin' Thai boys and their football coach found alive...Man walks from a burning building with skin hanging off his...Share this articleAnd after finishing second in the group stage - following a 1-0 defeat to Belgium, where both sides fielded weakened teams - fans are now hoping to get the show back on the road and land a quarter final place  against one of Switzerland or Sweden, who are currently doing battle in this afternoon's fixture.One-time England starlet turned pundit Owen perfectly summed up the nation's mindset, writing: 'We've been beaten by the only decent team we've faced yet the country is convinced we can win the World Cup... and I'm starting to believe too!' Hilarious tweets show how many have woken up this morning feeling hopeful but scared. One woman pondered: 'Is it okay if I phone in sick because I am so nervous?'           Former England striker turned pundit Michael Owen perfectly summed up the nation's logic defying belief, writing: 'we've been beat by the only decent team we've faced yet the country is convinced we can win the World Cup... and I'm starting to believe too!'          WAG Rebekah Vardy wasn't keeping her allegiances close to her chest todayOne fan wrote shortly after 7am: 'I can't work out whether I'm excited or nervous, all I know is I need a fag and a I need beer and I haven't had either in years.'Iain Shepherd posted: 'Feeling sick with worry and nerves and the game isn't on for another 12 hours. It's a huge chance. Come on England!' While Braden Valles wrote: 'I am literally only focused on the match tonight now, not going to lie.'And another said: 'Sitting here eating my breakfast and now on simulation number 167 of how tonight's game could pan out.' Popular pundit and former England and Arsenal hero Ian Wright shared a picture of himself being embraced by manager Southgate during their playing days. Wright geed up his followers with a tweet encouraging everyone to get behind the Three Lions. The former star man will be a pundit for ITV tonight when England kick off. Former England captain Rio Ferdinand  sent a tub-thumping message to Southgate's Lions today urging them to play with energy and power and quality to overcome Colombia.The slick centreback issue the rallying call on Instagram, where a number of the squad have been active in the days up to tonight's crunch clash.          Fans have already endured a roller coaster of emotions having gone from apathy to elation and then disappointment as England's World Cup has progressed so far - but a victory over Colombia would see a tidal wave of excitement sweep the nation as the draw opens up extremely favourably for England          The last time the two sides met was back in 2005 for a friendly where England won 3-2Gareth Southgate's team must get past the impressive Colombians who topped a difficult group containing Japan, Poland and Senegal. The last time the two sides met was back in 2005 for a friendly where England won 3-2. They haven't met competitively since 1998 where David Beckham and Darren Anderton gave the Three Lions a comfortable 2-0 win at the World Cup in France. But a strong squad built around the Real Madrid star man Rodriguez, who shot to fame at the last World Cup in Brazil as the tournament's top goal scorer, will prove a heady task for England's young side. Such is the anticipation that in Parliament, the Cabinet has informed whips to install TVs in the Commons smoking rooms to persuade MPs to stay and vote.            Popular pundit and former England and Arsenal hero Ian Wright shared a picture of himself being embraced by manager Southgate during their playing days. Wright geed up his followers with a tweet encouraging everyone to get behind the Three Lions.           Former England defender turned pundit Rio Ferdinand sent a tub-thumping message to Southgate's Lions today urging them to play with energy and power    Fans have been sharing their nerves ahead of the fixture tonight          England fans will be vastly outnumbered by Colombian supporters in tonight’s World Cup knockout match here as a mix of fear and hope descended on the travelling fans.Only around 5000 England fans are expected inside the Spartak Stadium while Colombia have a reported 50,000 fans who have travelled to Russia.Supporters must have official fan ids to buy tickets and these were granted to 13,000 England fans while more than three times as many Colombians received them.The official English allocation was 1,500, but several thousand supporters have purchased them through touts and unofficial online re-sellers with prices reaching £500 and more.          Gareth Southgate's team must get past the impressive Colombians who topped a difficult group containing Japan, Poland and Senegal.Fans wearing England shirts were hard to find among the sea of yellow Colombian shirts last night in Moscow’s Red Square.One fan Seb King, 34, from Bristol said: ‘There just aren’t as many England supporters around as in other World Cups.‘The tickets have been very hard to get hold of. I got mine through a corporate hospitality sponsor for my business.‘When I got here today, I found one group of England supporters in a bar and they said they were being careful not to wear their shirts because of warnings that Russians might attack us.          Fans wearing England shirts were hard to find among the sea of yellow Colombian shirts last night in Moscow’s Red Square. One fan Seb King, 34, from Bristol said: ‘There just aren’t as many England supporters around as in other World Cups‘But I’ve seen no sign of any tension. There’s mainly Mexicans, Spanish, Russian and Colombian fans here and everybody is having a great time, although its very noisy.‘I hope the few thousand England fans at the match make enough noise to give our team a 12th man. I’m confident we can win although my heart won’t easily take penalties if it goes to that.’Melissa Summers, 25, from Hull, added: ‘I got in last night and my ticket came from a Russian friend who I went to college with.‘I am so nervous I can’t tell you. I can’t sleep and I suppose its a mix of fear and hope. I so much want England to win and I know I am so lucky to be at the match when there are so many people at home who would love to be here.’A Colombian fan Raphael Santos, 58, from Medellín, said: ‘We want a good match with England and then to beat them.‘It is not gonna be easy for either side as the pressure is going to be much. But we will attack England and defend against your Harry Kane for the full 90 minutes. We will win this match.’ITV is reported to be expecting more than 20 million viewers for its coverage of the match which kicks off at 7pm, despite claims that the channel is a jinx for England.Superstitious fans fear the Three Lions face elimination from the competition after it was revealed that since 1998, England have won just nine per cent of world Cup matches screened by ITV.In comparison, England have won a staggering 69 per cent of games shown on the BBC.          Superstitious fans fear the Three Lions face elimination from the competition after it was revealed that since 1998, England have won just nine per cent of world Cup matches screened by ITVBoth of the nation's opening wins against Tunisia and Panama were broadcast on BBC, yet the 1-0 defeat was on ITV and led to calls for the game to be switched onto BBC.But ITV football anchor Mark Pougatch Tweeted: ‘ Yes, yes I’m well aware that apparently England’s fate is all down to which channel they’re shown on.‘Well, according to Henry Ford, “History is bunk.” So come along for the ride with ITV.’Clive Tyldesley and former England manager Glenn Hoddle will provide the commentary to a programme ITV hope will become the most watched programme of 2018.BBC said 18.3 million tuned in for its coverage of Tunisia v England which ended 1-2, while ITV said its audience peaked at 18.6 million for England’s defeat by Belgium in the third group game.Football Supporters representative Kevin Miles said: ‘The English FA returned 2000 tickets because there was no interest in them.‘The Colombians have sold out there allocation so there will be twice as many of their supporters in the stadium plus the many more who have bought them unofficially.‘I think the game is going to be 50-50 as the Colombians are very confident.‘It has been a great tournament without any trouble at all and just like it should be, all the nations mixing and enjoying he football.’

title: Allies Jacob Rees Mogg sound PR firms Tory leadership bid
story: Allies of Jacob Rees-Mogg (pictured) apparently sought advice from PR experts on how to exploit the Brexiteer's cult following among activists  Theresa May (pictured in meeting Dutch counterpart Mark Rutte in the Hague today) faces a potentially decisive battle with her own Cabinet over future relations with the EUWhile stopping short of totally ruling out a bid today, Mr Rees-Mogg pointed out that since the 1920s the Conservatives in government had always chosen a former chancellor, home secretary or foreign secretary.Pressed in a podcast for the ConservativeHome website on whether he would put his name forward, he replied: 'There isn't a contest. I am technically eligible to become Pope, which is open to all Catholic males, but the College of Cardinals has not elected a non-cardinal since, I think, Urban IV. 'I'm very unlikely to be the next Pope and I'm very unlikely to be the next Prime Minister, for exactly the same reason. Though technically eligible, it is not the way history will go.' He joked: 'The papacy would be fantastic. I would be infallible, which is better than is given to most politicians.'  Mr Rees-Mogg named Home Secretary Sajid Javid and Environment Secretary Michael Gove as 'first-class candidates' to succeed Theresa May when there is a vacancy. And he appeared to tip Mr Javid as the more likely choice, noting that, during periods in power, the Conservative Party has always chosen a former chancellor, home secretary or foreign secretary as its leader. Asked if the party might depart from that tradition, the North East Somerset MP said: 'It's very unlikely, because Sajid has shown so successfully in his relatively brief period as Home Secretary that holding the seals of office means you can get things done, and that gives you an ability to show people what you can really do, and I think that's been so important for him.' Mr Rees-Mogg has positioned himself as the champion of 'clean' Brexit, delivering a stark public warning to Mrs May yesterday that breaking 'red lines' in negotiations could collapse her administration.Theresa May's as opaque as the glass in an old municipal...Share this articleThe intervention by the Old Etonian and investment banker brought a furious response from some ministers who branded him 'insolent' and 'ideological' - although Boris Johnson defended his right to speak out.The North East Somerset MP has become an unlikely hit with grassroots activists for his traditional Conservative views and 'young fogey' style.He currently heads the 60-strong group of Eurosceptic Conservative MPs.However, so-called 'Moggmentum' movement appears to have cooled amid a backlash over the devout Catholic's hardline views on abortion and gay marriage.A source told The Times that PR firms had been approached. 'They were asked to explain how, if Jacob was speaking at a university, they would go about maximising the publicity and harvesting the greatest number of supporters who could later be converted into voting Tory members,' the source said.Veteran Tory MP Sir Bill Cash, a close friend of Mr Rees-Mogg, said he 'didn't recognise' a claim that he had been involved in interviewing PR firms and raising financial backing.           Ministers attacked Mr Rees-Mogg over his Brexit stance yesterday, with Alistair Burt and Sir Alan Duncan among those who accused him of 'lecturing and threatening' the PM          Fellow minister Richard Harrington also waded into the row to condemn Mr Rees-Mogg's comments          Senior Tory MP Sir Nicholas Soames said Mr Rees-Mogg should 'shut up' and accused him of making empty threats - saying he was 'all gong and no dinner' Mr Rees-Mogg has laughed off the idea of becoming leader and insists he is unaware of any fledgling campaign.'I have absolutely no knowledge of this,' he said. Yesterday there were reports that backers of Mr Rees-Mogg had raised a £750,000 war chest in case there is a leadership contest.A pro-Brexit MP has teamed up with a former UKIP member to assemble a fighting fund, according to the Express.A senior Tory said: 'We have given up on Theresa May and the current Cabinet. The membership love Jacob.'

title: How Prince Philip came close landed Britains nuclear test site
story: Newly surfaced documents show the Duke of Edinburgh visited Christmas Island in the South Pacific shortly after Operation Grapple, which saw the UK carry out nuclear weapons tests and hydrogen bomb explosions          Mechanics working on a Douglas Dakota aircraft of the RAF Transport Command on Christmas Island (Kiritimati) in the Central Pacific Ocean, during preparations for the Operation Grapple British nuclear weapons tests at the Island, May 1957      Why Meghan Markle and Kate Middleton can't wear wedges...Prince William 'pledges to make peace in the Middle East his...Share this article'I lost my youngest daughter when she was 13 after she was taken ill aged 11. Her disease has never been disclosed to me, nor have her medical records.' The Ministry of Defence has been contacted for comment.            The designers of the experiment admitted the pilot would have little or no shielding from the radiation from above the waist in comparison to other crew members  Prior to the test, scientists expected the pilot to receive a greater dose of radiation to the head. The crew also war testicular badges which recorded 'significantly lower levels' which 'are of interest and cheer in relation to the possibility of genetic damage'          An RAF serviceman having his hair cut on Christmas Island (Kiritimati) in the Central Pacific Ocean, during preparations for the Operation Grapple British nuclear weapons tests at the Island, May 1957          The documents show that the aircrew were test subjects to assess the effectiveness of experimental radiation dosage measuring equipment          Squadron Leader Eric Denson (pictured) suffered chronic headaches and eventually killed himself in the wake of the Cold War experimentThis year sensational new files were discovered by Shirley Denson, 83, the widow of a pilot who flew in one MoD experiment in 1958.Shirley, who lives in Morden, south London, obtained the papers afters years of research into her husband Eric's service.She believes radiation is the cause of the birth defects like extra teeth in her family. One young relative was recently born with an extra urinary tract.Her husband had suffered such a high dose of radiation to his head he went on to have chronic headaches which led him to kill himself in 1976.Eric and Shirley had already had one daughter together before he was involved in the experiment. She was born healthy.However, 37 per cent of their descendants from children born after Eric passed through the radiation cloud were born with defects or unexplained medical conditions.These included skull deformities, missing or extra teeth and spinal problems.          The MoD continues to deny that Eric and his crew were subjects of an experiment, despite the emergence of new papersTwo of his four children with Shirley were born with abnormalities, as were some of their grandchildren and great-grandchildren.RAF hero Eric was involved in early tests into the radiation caused by atomic and hydrogen bombs.In 1958 he was stationed in the Pacific Ocean on Malden Island and Christmas Island - the site of Operation Grapples, which saw the UK carry out some of its earliest nuclear weapons tests.Eric was ordered to fly his Canberra B6 bomber through a cloud left in the wake of a 2.8 megaton nuclear explosion on April 28, 1958, documents reveal.X-ray badges were stuck to his seat to measure the barrage of radiation as he and two others entered the cloud.They were placed behind his head, on both armrests and by his groin.The documents reveal 'care was taken to ensure as little shielding effect as possible' was given to the X-ray badges. Of course, this meant Eric and his crew became vulnerable to the deadly radiation.The document was an Atomic Weapons Establishment paper looking at ways of testing the badges to make sure they were accurate.They detail the exact amount of radiation absorbed by the head, arms and groin and the bomber's pilot, navigator and wireless operator.They also note the time spent inside the cloud, the height of the plane and the time the bomber entered the cloud after the bomb detonated.The documents goes on to set out the pros and cons of the badges in measuring radiation. They also suggest re-running the experiment with more badges.          One of the documents showed Flight Lieutenant Denson recorded a radiation reading of 13 Roentgens after carrying out the flightWhen Eric's bomber touched down after the test he began to experience vomiting and developed a rash - common symptoms of radiation poisoning.The documents, written by scientists running the experiments, show that Eric, who was 24 at the time, had his head exposed to 65 years' worth of normal ­background ­radiation.This amounted to 17,500 dental X-rays worth of radiation during just six minutes of flight.The badge placed near Eric's groin recorded a dose of 8.8 Roentgens - about 30 years' worth of background radiation.In total he received 18.8Rs, the worst of the three-man crew which flew that day.Shirley is seeking an apology from the Ministry of Defence, who have insisted veterans were not used as guinea pigs during nuclear tests.

title: Boardmaster Festival medics ignored teenagers pleas help
story: Pictured: George Zographou tragically died after contracting meningitis b A teenager died after festival medics failed to pick up on the signs of meningitis and left him on a tent floor in a coma.George Zographou, 18, was shaking and vomiting but doctors told his parents his illness wasn't serious with his mother asked to pay for a taxi to take him to hospital.But the sixth form student went into cardiac arrest on the tent floor and died days later in hospital.He had only just completed his A levels at a well-regarded college in his home city of Bristol. A government report released yesterday revealed how George's pleas for help fell on deaf ears. He arrived at the three-day music event in Newquay, Cornwall, last August and immediately fell ill.The youngster had not been drinking alcohol and spent the first night in his tent being sick with cramps in the back of his legs. He could only crawl on his hands and knees, the report read, and was not able to walk without help.   Security teams called the medics, who took him to the tent on a buggy. He continued to throw up, had low blood pressure and an increased heart rate.          George arrived at the three-day music event in Newquay, Cornwall, last August and immediately fell ill, spending his first night in his tent throwing up His mother called the medics and explained his heart rate was too high, and he was given morphine. A rash developed on his left foot, and the young man was diagnosed with dehydration and a stress fracture.George became agitated, and he was put on the floor. The report read: 'His mum, via the phone, asked that he be sent to hospital. The doctor said it was not an emergency so he would need to go in a taxi and pay.'Students and irresponsible landlords leave mountains of...Another reason to hope England's game doesn't go to...'He's expecting them to walk through the door': Boy, four,...WAGs can help England win the World Cup: Rebekah Vardy says...Share this articleShe pleaded for George to be taken to hospital, but the medics did not budge. Worried, George's parents drove down to Cornwall to bring him to hospital themselves, he was moved to a welfare tent.By that point, George had become 'agitated and aggressive' and lost consciousness. Staff were told to provide one-on-one observation, and they thought he had fallen asleep.'George was in fact in a coma and soon after went into cardiac arrest,' the working group's report read. 'He was blue lighted to hospital and on life support for five days.' His tragic case has been highlighted in a government report released yesterday.          The youngster had not been drinking alcohol and spent the first night in his tent being sick with cramps in the back of his legsHealth Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised to George's parents and also the family of Izzy Gentry, who also died after her meningitis was not diagnosed quickly enough. The report intends to raise awareness about the deadly illness and help medical staff and volunteers at festivals and mass gatherings to be able to recognise the signs  early. Izzy was only 16 years old when she was sent home from the Bristol Royal Infirmary with gastroenteritis instead of meningitis. The coroner ruled her death had been contributed to by neglect.After meeting the families, Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised and commissioned the report, which makes 12 recommendations. It includes listening to parents, better care at festivals and more awareness to the illness.          Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt apologised to George's parentsIzzy complained of headaches and not feeling well. There had been a meningitis case two weeks earlier at St Brendan's Sixth Form College, where both she and Geroge were pupils.Izzy developed a high temperature, became lethargic and soon started vomiting and developed neck and limb pain.She was taken by ambulance to the BRI, with paramedics warning of potential sepsis and meningitis.At triage, the doctor made an initial examination and diagnosed her with gastroenteritis, sending her home with fluids and painkillers, making no reference to meningitis.At home, she worsened and suffered a fit, and she was rushed back to hospital. Izzy fell unconscious by the time she got to A&ampE and doctors said it was serious and she was taken into intensive care. Less than half an hour later, she was diagnosed with meningitis.Izzy was stabilised, but her condition got worse and her organs shut down. An inquest concluded her death had been contributed by neglect.The report made 12 recommendations, including asking all medical staff and volunteers at festivals to to know the signs of meningitis.Those staff and volunteers need to checked through by the Care Quality Commision (CQC) and communication also needs to be improved.The working group also wants Public Health England to review its leaflets on vaccinations and meningitis.

title: Greek athletes olive oil traditional wrestling rivals hands rivals trousers
story: Each one-on-one battle can take from five seconds, to up to 40 minutes including added time, depending on strategy and tactics. The best way to succeed is to avoid the slippery torsos, and aim for fellow competitors’ trousers, called kismet          Limbering up before going onto the grassed wrestling zone, these competitors have already been covered in olive oil for the traditional event, which dates back two millennia. Oil wrestling is believed to be the closest to ancient Greek wrestling in style. However, in ancient times, the Greeks would have competed naked, as they did in all sports          Bare torso, and with bare feet, this wrestler is donning thick trousers made of calfskin leather. Some wrestlers also wear jeans. The trousers the men wear are made of thick leather in a traditional design called kisbet. In recent years manufacturers have changed from traditional buffalo to calfskin. While durable, sometimes they are torn apart in the fighting          Wrestlers covered in olive oil fight in an annual traditional oil wrestling competition in the northern Greek village of Sochos. Muscular men walk around the lawn, which is turned into a wrestling ring, to the tune of traditional music, with their torsos slathered in olive oil for the yearly festival that blends the traditions of ancient Greece and more modern times          Fights take place simultaneously in a large field, and unlike most combat sports there is no set field or arena. The wrestlers are free to roam around as the fight takes them, and are typically followed by a referee. Unlike Greco-Roman wrestling, which relies heavily on technical ability, oil wrestling is more a test of endurance          In tears: a wrestler covered in olive oil reacts after taking part in an annual traditional oil wrestling competition in the northern Greek village of Sochos. The oil makes it harder for the wrestler to grip opponents, so this type of combat needs a certain strategy, besides strength, to succeed          Oil wrestling is one of the oldest sports in the world, which dates back to the ancient city of Babylon but is still practiced across Turkey and in northern parts of Greece. There is no score in the event. The winner is the man who manages to throw his opponent onto the ground so that his shoulders touch the soil          Prior to the matches, wrestlers cover their bodies in olive oil as they prepare to compete in the event. It is not unusual for competitors to oil one another, above, to show mutual respect. The traditional sport of oil wrestling in Greece has continued from generation to generation          Spectators watch as wrestlers covered in oil take part in an annual traditional oil wrestling competition, in the northern Greek village of Sochos. Fights take place simultaneously in a large field, and unlike most combat sports there is no set field or arena. The wrestlers are free to roam around as the fight takes them, and are typically followed by a referee          Wrestled to the ground: the annual event promotes and spreads the sport of wrestling, with spectators, including tourists, watching as competitors test each participant's strength and skills. Unlike in boxing, isions in oil wrestling do not only take into account weight, but also age and track record - meaning there is often little similarity in physiques between competitorsJudy Murray says tennis faces its own #MeToo moment because...Dramatic pictures capture the moment a tourist who floated...Share this article

title: Heatwave 2018 UKs hottest summer record
story: Wimbledon fans queue for tickets for day two of the tournament. This year’s Wimbledon Championships could have one of the hottest days everChief Meteorologist, Will Lang, said: ‘The heatwave conditions will continue to affect pretty much all parts of the UK over the next few days.‘Although peak temperatures may not be quite as high as we have seen this week, we will still see temperatures widely in the mid to high 20’s  with 30C or more still possible across southern and some central parts of England.’However, that is still a few degrees short of the hottest temperature recorded in the UK.That honour goes to Faversham in Kent in 2003. On August 10, the hottest ever temperature in the UK was recorded there, hitting a mighty 38.5C.The summer of 2003 was an incredibly hot one, with Scotland’s Greycook recording 32.9C one day earlier. It was the hottest temperature ever recorded in Scotland until June 28, 2018.That summer wasn’t the hottest overall, however. That title goes to the summer of 1976, where for 15 days towards the end of June, temperatures in all four nations topped 32C and Cheltenham recorded 35.9C at the start of July.In Dorset and Devon, no measurable rain fell for a staggering 45 days, which led to the passing of the Drought Act and water rationing.It is thought that temperatures will climb over the next two weeks, hitting 33C in the first week of July before potentially topping 35C next week.Dr Thomas Waite of PHE of Public Health England said: ‘It’s vitally important that we keep an eye on friends, family and neighbours who may be at risk.‘For others, the best thing to do is avoid the sun during the hottest parts of the day, carry water with you when travelling and if going out to large events, and we know lots of people will be watching football this week: think what you can do stay cool.’See here for more information on how hot the weather has to be for school and work to get cancelled. What is Cheryl&#8217s surname following her split from Liam Payne?Heatwave 2018: When was the UK's hottest summer on recordWho is Morgan Evans? story: A five-year-old girl, pictured left, sustained facial injuries, right, after being knocked down by a yob on a scrambler bike in Bolton          Family have shared the images and footage on Facebook to try to track the culprit downFootage shows three lads surrounding the scrambler-type bike on a pavement on a housing estate.One of the youths then jumps on the machine and roars down the street.As he passes a blue car he crashes into the child – sending her sprawling - but doesn't even stop or look around as he turns into a side street and disappears.Horrified children are left in tears after helicopter...Share this articleHer cousin Jess Gleaves posted on Facebook: 'My beautiful little cousin was run over by a 15-year-old on a motorbike.'She set one foot out of her gate and went flying! She's 5....ending up in hospital and the bastard didnt even stop! Police cant arrest him till he has been named. Please help us find out who he is! Poor princess.'          Family members said the girl, pictured, spent three days in hospital after the incident          The incident was caught on a dashcam and the biker, pictured, did not stop after the collisionA neighbour added: 'A lot of you may of seen the post I posted the other week of my neighbours little girl being involved in a hit and run on the street.'We now have the footage off a dash cam by someone driving past at the time of the incident.'I'm posting this as still nobody has been arrested for this even though we have been given a name on who it was, any information is appreciated. 'This poor little girl spent 3 days in hospital because of the wanker and it could of been a lot worse!! She's very lucky. Please share.'

title: Stoke house gutted blaze SUNLIGHT reflected glass table garden
story: This house in Knypersley in Stoke-on-Trent was gutted by a fire started when sunlight reflected off a glass table in the back gardenA Staffordshire Fire and Rescue Service spokesman said: 'Crews from Newcastle and Kidsgrove attended and the detached property was well alight on arrival.'Some of the decking at the back of the house had to be cut away as crews extinguished the fire.'It was caused by sunlight reflecting on a glass table outside in the back garden. The occupier was upstairs by managed to get out of the house safely.Britain screams for WATER! UK battles double crisis as taps...Heatwave raises lost 'Atlantis' village from its watery...Share this article'Please take care during this heatwave and be mindful of keeping reflective items, such as mirrors or glass, out of direct sunlight.'The service also took to Twitter, posting an image of the damage and wrote: 'Please be careful in this #heatwave. 'A house fire in Knypersley was caused by sunlight reflecting on a glass table outside.
