title: Corbyns Labour Party breeding softcore Holocaust denial claims leading academic
story: Deborah Lipstadt (file), who rose to prominence in a legal battle with historian David Irving in 2000 after accusing him of Holocast denial, said anti-Semitism was 'embedded' in LabourDr Lipstadt said full-blown Holocaust denial had been 'seriously weakened' with people who promote it widely seen as 'at best loony at worst hateful anti-Semites'.But speaking at the Holocaust Education Trust's annual conference in Westminster, London, said: 'Softcore Holocaust denial is where everything becomes a genocide. 'Softcore Holocaust denial is where people say 'I'm so tired of hearing about this, why am I always hearing about the Holocaust, too much about the Holocaust, oh you Jews and the Holocaust, jokes about the Holocaust…' Downing Street 'bans Donald Trump from meeting Nigel Farage'...'The stakes are higher than we have ever known': PM pleads...Share this articleJeremy Corbyn's (pictured in the Commons last night) Labour is breeding 'softcore' Holocaust denial, Dr Lipstadt warned'But it's more than that - it's a form of anti- Semitism. That's the kind of softcore denial I worry about much more. It's subtly anti-Semitic and its clearly denial because it rewrites history.' A Labour Party spokesperson said: 'Jeremy Corbyn has been absolutely clear that he is a militant opponent of anti-Semitism and is committed to driving it out of politics and our society.'Labour has deep roots in the Jewish community and is campaigning to increase support and confidence in our Party among Jewish people in the UK.'Any complaints of anti-Semitism, including Holocaust denial, are taken extremely seriously and are fully investigated, and appropriate disciplinary action, in line with Party rules and procedures.'Labour's new General Secretary Jennie Formby has made it her first priority to speed up and strengthen our procedures and to develop a programme of political education to create deeper awareness and understanding about all forms of antisemitism.'          She named Ken Livingstone as an example of Labour's problem. The ex-Mayor of London quit the party in May after more than two years of criticism over his rants about Hitler

title: One Britains biggest hoarders vows CLEAN squalid home junk
story: Arthur Watson at his flat which he says he is going to clean up after almost three decades of hoarding          Mr Watson said he is planning on having people round after his daughter marries her boyfriendHe said he now wants to have a few guests around, especially as his daughter Anna gets married to her fiance Matthew, in August.There is currently a mountain of washing up and Arthur's carpet is barely visible beneath the huge piles of newspapers and possessions at the bottom floor flat.  He said: 'I am quite happy, but I have got to the point where I could do with a little tidy up.'My daughter has given up on me. She knows I am a lost cause. She thinks that if I have not poisoned myself by now then I probably never will.          Arthur Watson, 69, has been collecting everything from old newspapers to bicycles for more than 30 years. His small home, which he bought in 1982, is packed in every room with piles of junk          Mr Watson is getting set to tackle the mounds of rubbish and is planning on trips to the dump'I have a few friends around the fish and chip shop, and I have invited them around for barbecue, but never accept my invitations. I think they have heard my house is a bit of a tip.'Arthur, a former museum curator, is not getting rid of everything though and insists some of the items could come in handy one day - including the six children's bicycles he stores away - and says others have sentimental value.He even has the remnants of a handprint his daughter made as a child on his kitchen wall using the goo from a mackerel he was gutting more than a decade ago.Arthur, of Plymouth, Devon, said: 'It is not like I am a miser, I don't have any gold.          A mountain of washing up will need to be tackled by the hoarder who has been hanging onto his stuff for decadesBurglar who killed coin collector by stuffing a sock in his...¿Hoarder¿ dies in a house blaze after firefighters were...Share this article'There is nothing of any value here. In fact if burglars see my flat they think I have already been burgled. I am hoarding memories, and the older you get the more of them I have.'Me and my wife orced more than 20 years ago, and I suppose you could say that was a definite turning point.'She was compulsive with cleanliness, and I had to do all the cleaning, and cooking, everything. It was a bit tricky.'The collecting didn't immediately get worse, but everything I could sweep up I have swept up.'Arthur added that he had kept several things because he thought they might be useful.He said his empty wine bottles are earmarked for blackcurrant wine for example and a portaloo from his camping days makes an emergency toilet.Other items have somewhat odd sentimental value, like the huge stacks of copies of his local newspaper the Plymouth Herald which make the floor uneven.He added: 'My grandfather used to work for the Evening Herald as it was then so I could never throw them out.'          The kitchen is rammed with dirty dishes which Mr Watson says he is going to clear out this coming weekend          Arthur, who started his extreme 'hoarding' after he orced from his wife more than 20 years, revealed he was finally hiring a van and planning several trips to the dump          Some of the items collected by Mr Watson include huge piles of books and newspapers           There is barely room to sit round at Mr Watson's house but he wants to clean his act up to have guests over He insists that he usually finds what he wants amid the mess but confessed his 'retrieval system was not 100 per cent foolproof'.Amidst the chaos there are some items which are relatively neatly stored on shelves and in a filing cabinet and the wedding invite has a special place suspended from a string across the living room.Three years ago he was threatened him with legal action by his local council to tidy up and he cited the Magna Carta in his defence. But he added that no prosecution ever took place.Arthur says he will not call a contract cleaner in case they throw out something valuable amid the piles of papers and dirty dishes.

title: Young couple lost passports flight Greece sent home
story: Lewis Mundy and Kimberley Floyd, both 27, excitedly boarded a flight to Greece and tucked their passports into the magazine pocket of their seats. But after stepping off the jet they realised they did not have the documents and a search of the plane failed to find themLewis and Kimberly were unable to fly back out during the week and so had to forfeit the £1,400 holiday.'We were supposed to be sunning it up in Greece but instead ended up at Stansted,' said Lewis.'There's no sign of our passports and we've had no help, no compensation, nothing. We've done everything we could but no one seems to care.Man walks from a burning building with skin hanging off his...Desperate passengers cling on for their lives as ferry...Share this article'It was a nightmare, the biggest you could imagine.'The couple booked their week-long holiday to the five star Atki Hotel on the island of Kos with First Choice and flew out on a TUI jet from Gatwick in June.Lewis, of Portsmouth, who owns his own groundworks company, said: 'It was the first holiday we had together.          The devastated couple were then told they could not enter the country - and within 30 minutes were sent home'We boarded the plane to go to Greece, it was very exciting. We sat to watch a film and chilled out on the plane to pass the time.'They said they put their passports in a transparent plastic bag and tucked them into the seat pockets for the duration of the four-hour flight.But within minutes of stepping off the plane they realised they didn't have the documents and instantly tried to backtrack, but were told they couldn't re-board.Instead a member of staff conducted a search but quickly emerged to say they could not be found.The couple said they pleaded with staff to have another look and gave detailed instructions about where the passports were, but still they could not be found.Kimberley, also from Portsmouth said: 'I realised as soon as we got off the plane, it could only have been two minutes tops.'They told us we couldn't get back on the plane and the made us wait by the door to the airport while someone went to look but they said there was nothing there.'Their surprise turned to horror when they were told they would not be allowed into Greece and would have to return to the UK.Kimberley continued: 'We had people around us making sure we didn't leave.          Lewis and Kimberly were unable to fly back out during the week and had to forfeit the £1,400 holiday. 'We were supposed to be sunning it up in Greece but instead ended up at Stansted,' said Lewis'We were waiting for about 30 minutes for a flight back, we had to wait by the door. They tried to move us somewhere else but I refused.'There were people watching us like we were criminals.'After waiting for between 30 and 40 minutes the couple were put on the next flight back to the UK, and endured another four hour flight.Kimberley added: 'They didn't care, they gave us a boarding pass and chucked us on the next flight, we didn't get a choice - it was disgusting.'The couple have contacted First Choice and TUI but have not managed to locate their passports or had any offer of compensation.A TUI UK spokesperson said: 'We're sorry to hear of Mr Mundy and Ms Floyd's very rare experience on their flight to Greece.'As a result of not having their passports they were not allowed into the country and were flown back to the UK.'After searching the aircraft thoroughly we can confirm their passports were not found.'We would like to remind customers, as we generally do before they leave the aircraft, to ensure they have all their personal possessions with them and to take responsibility of their personal items at all times.'

title: Primary school cancels invite parents Pride playground parade slam teachers it
story: Heavers Farm Primary School had to cancel inviting parents to its Pride playground parade on Friday after some parents slammed the school's teachers for organising the event. Pictured: MP Steve Reed speaking to pupils at the event           MP Steve Reed spoke at the playground event and applauded the school for 'standing up for equality and ersity'           The south London school had planned for a celebratory parade on campus with families invited to witness 'the rainbow of things that make them and their family special'Susan Papas, headteacher of the school in South Norwood, told the Evening Standard: 'Some parents have taken exception to this. They feel the school is shoving LGBT issues down the kids' throats. This takes us back decades.'We thought we would celebrate Pride month so those children from LGBT families would feel included and to show the kids that children come from different families.'But some parents aren't happy with the term LGBT and don't want their children knowing about these terms or what they mean. 'We have had so many messages of support from many parents who are quite cross about this minority who they feel are spreading hateful messages.'Also speaking to the paper, mother Erica Chamberlain said she and her daughter Scarlett, five, were disappointed over the decision.She said: 'She'd been really excited about it, and what she was going to wear to it, so we were really disappointed.''The very nature of a Pride parade is to be proud — not celebrate it quietly and non-publicly.'Transsexual model makes history by becoming the first to...'Gay cure' therapy will be outlawed: Prime Minister Theresa...Share this article    But some parents insist they were right to want to protest, saying they wanted the chance to educate their children on such topicsAnother parent added: 'The parade was about teaching the kids love has no label and celebrating love in all its forms.' But some parents insist they were right to want to protest, saying they wanted the chance to educate their children on the topic.One said: 'There were dozens of us who were upset and waited outside the school office to demand a meeting when we heard what was being taught. 'I want to be able to educate my child on these things, it's not just a matter of religion or our religious beliefs.'Another mother added: 'A number of parents pulled their children out of the school for the parade entirely. They just didn't show up with their kids.'           Mother Jo Macfarlane tweeted in support of the school: 'Well done Heavers Farm for teaching kids about #Pride - it’s a multicoloured world and there’s space for us all. My daughter has embraced the theme with a rainbow skirt, sparkly headband and a superhero cape. So proud!'MP Steve Reed spoke at the playground event, and later tweeted: 'With the wonderful staff and children at for their Pride celebration - very proud of them for standing up for equality and ersity. ' Mother Jo Macfarlane tweeted in support of the school: 'Well done Heavers Farm for teaching kids about #Pride - it’s a multicoloured world and there’s space for us all. 'My daughter has embraced the theme with a rainbow skirt, sparkly headband and a superhero cape. So proud!' Pride event at London school axed after parents threaten protest | London Evening Standard

title: Embarrassing moment minister interrupted Siri Commons chamber
story: Amid puzzled laughter from MPs in the chamber, Speaker John Bercow said: 'What a very rum business that is.'          As Gavin Williamson spoke in the Commons today (pictured), a disembodied voice could clearly be heard saying: 'I've found something on the web about Syria.'Jacob Rees-Mogg says he is as likely to become POPE as PM as...'The stakes are higher than we have ever known': PM pleads...Chancellor could hike taxes on fuel and alcohol to help fund...'I wouldn't go against him': Ex-Cabinet minister Iain Duncan...Share this articleAmid puzzled laughter from MPs, Speaker John Bercow said: 'What a very rum business that is.'Belatedly realising what was happening, Mr Williamson groped for the phone in his pocket to turn it off. 'It is very rare that you are heckled by your own mobile phone,' he joked nervously. 'It is a new parliamentary convention, without a doubt.'Having dealt with the interruption, Mr Williamson said he hoped he could continue 'without help and support from Siri'.          In April, transport minister Jo Johnson was talking about Syria on the BBC's Question Time (pictured) when he suffered a similar unwanted response from his mobileIt is not the first time a minister has faced public humiliation at the hand of the iPhone's virtual helper.In April, transport minister Jo Johnson was talking about Syria on the BBC's Question Time when he suffered a similar unwanted response from his mobile.'This is technology in action,' he quipped as he switched off the handset, before bravely pressing on with his point.

title: Boy sits edge rooftop 33 STOREY building children 324 feet high
story: A boy is filmed dangerously sitting at the edge of a rooftop at a 33-storey building in China (left). He then climbs along the ridge to the top to join his friends (right)According to Shengyang Daily, the neighbour, Mr Wang, noticed the group of children while he was in his 27th floor home in Bijie district of Guizhou Province on June 29.Toddler gets his hand jammed in a lift while playing with...Remains of burial horses from 2,700 years ago are found in...BEE careful! Woman is left with a VERY swollen face after...Share this articleFootage shows around six children standing on the rooftop and one little boy climbing up from a tiny ledge. Mr Wang did not alert the police or the security guard, instead he shared the video to a closed discussion group. He explained that he wanted to warn the parents and hoped they could stop their children from playing on the rooftop. He said he also wanted to remind the public not to leave the children unattended during playtime.          Another five, six children can be seen playing at some 324 feet high above ground          A neighbour posted the video to warn the parents not to leave their children unattendedIt's believed all the children went back home safely without any injuries. Mr Wang said this is the fourth time he had seen children playing on the rooftop.'I wish the management can do something about it to avoid similar incidents from happening again,' he told Shenyang Daily.Three weeks ago, two young boys were seen playing on a 12-storey residential building in east China.The incident brought concerns of safety measures and residents urged the management to take actions to prevent young children going up to the rooftops.

title: Adorable moment chimpanzee reunited foster parents
story: Limbani was seen drinking through a straw when he hears someone call his name from behind (left) and sees it is his foster parent Jorge (right)The chimp makes sure that his arms are wrapped tightly around the man's neck and his legs around his waist during the loving embrace.Limbani is then quickly distracted after seeing Jorge's wife, Tania, walk into the room. He lets out another excited sound before reaching out to her and giving her a cuddle.The heart-warming footage was posted on Instagram by the Zoological Wildlife Foundation in Miami, who say the couple helped provide the animal with 'around the clock care for the first few months of his life'.Limbani is now staying at the zoo, but regularly sees the couple who raised him when they visit. And even though there can be months between visits, the foundation said the Limbani's reaction is 'always the same' when he is reunited with them.Limbani was rejected after he was born with pneumonia and rejected by his mother.  Limbani could not hide his excitement as he gives Jorge a hug (left). Limbani hit headlines in January when a video of him with a Mastiff dog, named Bruno cuddling went viral.Another video on the Zoo's website shows 'bundle of love' Limbani playing with a golden Tabby tiger cub.

title: Footage shows undertaking Mercedes driver swerving traffic
story: Peter Goodfellow, 36, was jailed for 11 months after the horrifying crash which sent the Mini spinning across three lanes          Video shows Goodfellow undertaking other vehicles as he whizzes down the motorway at dangerous speed.          These dramatic dash-cam images show the moment a speed maniac weaves in and out of motorway traffic at upwards of 100mph, before colliding into a mini at top speedHe was also found to have two bald tyres on his white Mercedes C250 vehicle at the time of the incident on July 19 last year.The smash happened on the M4 carriageway westbound, at the Leigh Delamere services near Chippenham.Goodfellow, of Swindon, Wiltshire, was sentenced at Swindon Crown Court last Friday to 11 months behind bars.Terrifying moment a baby in a buggy rolls off the pavement...Dramatic moment driver, 57, attempts to flee traffic stop...Share this articleHe was also disqualified from driving for 29 months, after which time he will need to retake his driving test. He must pay a victim surcharge of £140.The female driver of the Mini suffered minor injuries.PC Will Ayres, of Wiltshire Police Roads Policing Unit, said: 'Dash cam footage was invaluable in securing this conviction against Goodfellow.          The car hits the mini at top speed and sends it spinning across three lanes of traffic          eter Goodfellow, aged 36 years, was arrested after police arrived at the scene and requested dash-cam footage from nearby cars whose drivers had seen the incident'He is a dangerous driver who had no regard for other road users. This was a busy time of day on a busy stretch of the M4.'Goodfellow put other road users lives at risk, not just by driving at excess speed, but also undertaking vehicles which led to a collision and left an innocent driver with injuries.'Thankfully, these injuries were minor although the incident has no doubt really affected her.'Looking at the dash cam footage provided by a witness, it is so lucky that nobody was more seriously injured.'           The dangerous white Mercedes pictured moments before the incident          The driver of the white Mercedes C250 was also found to have to bald tyres on his car, meaning the grip on the wheels had been excessively worn down, making an accident much more likely

title: Meet BRAVEST football fans England Ramos family cheering Colombia tonight
story: The Ramos family's Colombia flag sticks out in a sea of red and white St George's flags on the Kirby Estate in Bermondsey, south-east London          Sandra Ramos, right, will be cheering on Colombia along with her sons Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and Kevin Jhonnes, 18, daughter Alejandra Ramos, 29, granddaughter Adeline, seven months and her American bulldog Troy, three, when they take on England in tonight's big matchFlagging an interest! Football fan who covered his estate in...Share this articleHer eldest son Jean-Paul Jhonnes echoes his mother's passion and he too is hoping that Colombia will win.'I was born here in England and London is my home but I am only supporting Colombia. They are my team. I don't know how it's going to go. It'll be very close, a difficult game.'The England supporters think it will be easy for them, but I don't think it will. Colombia are in a strong position and all the top teams are out. It's been a very unpredictable World Cup.'Jean-Paul, 19, who is currently training at a football academy dreams of making it as a professional player, says despite the rivalry there is a great community spirit on the Kirby Estate, in Bermondsey, south-east London.'Our neighbours are very nice. Most of them will be supporting England but it doesn't matter. They have invited us to watch the match with them on a projector downstairs.'We have invited family and friends to join us so hopefully we will be able to make ourselves heard.'We will be dancing the salsa and the bachata when Colombia score!  Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and his mother Mother Sandra Ramos, 48, will be cheering on Colombia from their second floor flat tonight while all of their neighbours support the Three Lions'It is a very important game. It feels like it is a semi-final match. Whoever wins tonight – Colombia or England – has a good chance to make the final.'Cheering on Colombia will be mother Sandra, 48, her sons Jean-Paul Jhonnes, 19, and Kevin Jhonnes, 18, her daughter Alejandra Ramos, 29, her granddaughter Adeline, seven months and her American bulldog Troy, three. Sandra added: 'There is a real community spirit here on the estate. My neighbours are very friendly.'A post-war housing development the heart of Bermondsey, the Kirby Estate has become an a tourist attraction after proud residents strung up 300 St George's flags – and a couple of Colombia tricolours – to mark the 2018 World Cup.School groups and foreign tourists are now flocking to the four-storey blocks to take in the sea of England flags.'There is a real community spirit here on the Kirby Estate,' Chris Dowse, 39, one of the organisers, told MailOnline.'We put letters through everyone's door saying we were going to put England flags on the balconies. Everyone was up for it.'And there are a few other flags as well – Colombian, Brazilian – and that's fine.'People say there's no communities left in London but there absolutely is.'We have people here from lots of different communities, lots of different backgrounds.'We wanted to have a barbecue to celebrate the estate so we put letters through all the doors. I never expected such a response.'I've been properly overwhelmed and humbled by how much everyone's come together.  Everyone on the Kirby Estate tonight will be huddled around a big screen cheering on the Three Lions besides the Ramos family who will be going for Colombia'I grew up in the 80s, back then it was exactly like this, all about the community.'The estate is old fashioned, it's just the way we are. Bermondsey people are known for it.'We've had school kids and tourists come and have a look at all the flags. It's mad.'I want people to come tonight to watch the match. Someone's going be happy and someone's going to be sad but it will be a great night.'

title: Animal outcasts sanctuary Britains wonderfully eccentric farm
story: No room in the barn for this nativity star: For the first few months of his life, Dougal was bottle-fed by members of the public at a farm park in their nativity scene. When he outgrew that and was being sent for slaughter, Manor Farm stepped in. ‘He’s a rascal,’ says Di. ‘Having been given lots of attention, he feels it’s his right to demand fuss from visitors, who are taken by surprise when he head-butts the back of their knees!’          Bullied pig called Simon: Partially-sighted and with deformed front legs, Simon was so terribly bullied by the bigger pigs he shared a sty with at another rescue centre that they asked Manor Farm to take him. ‘He was grossly overweight which didn’t help with his movement problems — if he was a human it’s like he’s walking on his wrists,’ says Di. ‘He’s now lost weight and is enjoying life with his friend Brooke. She chivvies him around all day and I give him strawberries and melon which he loves.’          Jack the VERY stroppy Donkey: Jack was the first non-hen to be taken in by Manor Farm rescue sanctuary after it came into being about seven years ago. ‘We bought the land for it with some money left to me by my Uncle Jack,’ says Di, ‘so when a donkey sanctuary asked me to look after a donkey called Jack it seemed meant to be. The only thing is — he’s nothing like my Uncle Jack who was very gentle whereas donkey Jack is quite stroppy!’Less than a decade ago, Di and Alan were both running businesses from their Nottinghamshire village home.Now they’re also running an animal sanctuary that currently cares for more than 100 farmyard creatures. And not just any creatures. They take in the ones no one else wanted, rejected because they were disabled, had health problems, special needs or simply grew too old.Or, in the case of the many rescued from petting zoos, simply because they grew up. ‘People imagine these animals are living a lovely life in the petting zoo until they die naturally,’ says Di, ‘but that’s not so in the majority of cases.Adorable moment Limbani the chimpanzee shrieks with joy and...Fury at female Kentucky hunter who posted sickening photos...Share this article‘Lambs can be bred out of season to be Christmas attractions to be bottle-fed by visitors but once they’ve grown out of the cute stage, they go into the food chain.’What’s more, they often come to her emaciated, neglected and infested with parasites. Then the battle is on to save their lives. That battle costs Manor Farm Charitable Trust up to £100,000 a year — around a fifth of which are vets’ bills.‘Our vets are constantly challenged by the ageing of our animals,’ Di admits.No wonder — it’s rare farmyard creatures live more than a year or two before going to be slaughtered.          Blind Stevie's a littler wonder: When blind Stevie the Mallard duck came to Manor Farm, they knew he needed a friend to guide him round. ‘I chose a girl called Wanda,’ says Di, ‘because female ducks are louder than the boys and I believed he needed someone noisy to follow around.’ Stevie was found with big scabs over his eyes. ‘We didn’t know at first if he’d been attacked, if they were infected or even if he had eyes. He did — but he was blind.’ Now Wanda’s his guide duck.          Toothless OAP fed on a banana: Life’s left Dolly so scared of human strangers that when summer comes Di can’t call in a shearer —instead she has to do it herself with nail scissors. Dolly, a breeding nanny at a farm park, came to Manor Farm in 2012 when they started neglecting her because she’d become barren. ‘She barely had the strength to hold her head up,’ says Di. ‘But she had an indomitable spirit we could all do with.’ Dolly, who has no teeth, was fattened up with mashed banana and is now in the equivalent of her 90s.          Stumble, duck who live up to his name: Stumble may only have one leg but he’s still the scourge of the female ducks he shares his enclosure with. ‘He’s perfected the ability to jump on to a mate,’ says Di. ‘They all run but they can’t hide from him. Stumble’s leg had to be amputated after getting caught in fishing wire. He’s had a difficult summer because he’s moulted and lost his tail feather and wing tips — which help keep him stable. So he keeps falling over.’ And falling in love.          Goat that costs £3,000 to perk up: Of all the Manor Farm animals, Jo cost the most. So thin when Di rescued him from a petting zoo that he couldn’t hold his neck up, she nursed him back to health in her kitchen. ‘He came up to me as if to say “help me,” ’ she says. Jo was covered in lice and had digestive problems. ‘We nearly lost him several times — he was always the one needing the vet at midnight,’ says Di. But she doesn’t begrudge a penny of the £3,000 he cost. ‘He’s the sweetest creature,’ she says.But it’s not just the vets who have been learning. Di has too. ‘In 2010 I treated myself to four hens as a reward for completing an MA in creative writing and I found it was a slippery slope ,’ she says.A year later, a relative died, leaving her money to buy the six-acre field behind the house. Slowly the brood grew and the dozen or so enclosures now house 64 hens, 27 goats, two donkeys, one pony, two pigs and 30 sheep.Di now employs a full-time member of staff and three part-timers. Every day begins at 6am when she gets the feed ready. It ends at 10.30pm — earlier in winter — when she puts the animals to bed. She also finds time to run her publishing business (and Alan his marketing consultancy firm) which help bankroll Manor Farm.          Ewe with a stiff neck: Born with a twisted neck, Hilda was too deformed to breed and too skinny to slaughter so Di took the tiny ewe in. 'We were told she'd never take to humans,' she eat out of a trough because she'd never seen them before. But within a month she was letting us touch her and gradually she got a lust for life. Now she loves to be cuddled and her tail wags madly like a big dog          A goat the size of a pony: Ronnie, the Anglo Nubian goat, is the size of a Shetland pony. ‘They’re a large breed but he’s a particular giant,’ says Di, ‘and that’s how he ended up here — his elderly owner couldn’t cope with the size of him and was going to have him shot.’ So she did a 135-mile round trip to save him. ‘I knew he was big but even so it was a bit of a shock when I saw him.’Other money comes from corporate and personal donations and the sale of eggs and wool from the animals online. Apart from cash worries, there are other downsides. ‘I’ve had every injury known to man — I’ve lost a nail to a goat horn, been electrocuted by a fence and accidentally injected myself with goat antibiotics,’ says Di.But this pales into insignificance compared to the pain of losing one of their beloved creatures. The sanctuary is full so it’s only with the death of an animal that another can be saved. They come from farm parks, via social media or from other rescue centres.‘It is hard work,’ says Di, ‘but when you see the sheep feeding on the grass and the goats happy in their enclosure, it’s worth it.’          Hen healed in a roasting tray: Buffy the ex-battery hen was doing perfectly well at Manor Farm when she was sat on by another bird and left with a bruised back last winter. ‘One of my biggest joys was that we got Buffy back to health with daily physio,’ says Di. ‘Although I do feel a bit guilty that we kept her in a roasting tray so she could rest her neck on the edge of it. She’s still a bit stiff and walks with a bit of a goose step but is otherwise fine. And she now loves cuddles — every time you pass her she wants you to pick her up.’          Sheep who need a dentist: Dumpy is easy to spot: his teeth have grown so big, his jaw is deformed. ‘But you really couldn’t meet a sweeter sheep,’ says Di. She saved him from the slaughterhouse last year — he was on a trailer bound for it when the farmer’s daughter put out a social media appeal. ‘We all clubbed together to buy him and the farmer said we could have him — as long as we gave the money to Comic Relief,’ says Di. But those teeth keep the dentist busy.Manor Farm Charitable Trust | Lifelong sanctuary for livestock in need

title: Allies Jacob Rees Mogg sound PR firms Tory leadership bid
story: Allies of Jacob Rees-Mogg (pictured) apparently sought advice from PR experts on how to exploit the Brexiteer's cult following among activists  Theresa May (pictured in meeting Dutch counterpart Mark Rutte in the Hague today) faces a potentially decisive battle with her own Cabinet over future relations with the EUWhile stopping short of totally ruling out a bid today, Mr Rees-Mogg pointed out that since the 1920s the Conservatives in government had always chosen a former chancellor, home secretary or foreign secretary.Pressed in a podcast for the ConservativeHome website on whether he would put his name forward, he replied: 'There isn't a contest. I am technically eligible to become Pope, which is open to all Catholic males, but the College of Cardinals has not elected a non-cardinal since, I think, Urban IV. 'I'm very unlikely to be the next Pope and I'm very unlikely to be the next Prime Minister, for exactly the same reason. Though technically eligible, it is not the way history will go.' He joked: 'The papacy would be fantastic. I would be infallible, which is better than is given to most politicians.'  Mr Rees-Mogg named Home Secretary Sajid Javid and Environment Secretary Michael Gove as 'first-class candidates' to succeed Theresa May when there is a vacancy. And he appeared to tip Mr Javid as the more likely choice, noting that, during periods in power, the Conservative Party has always chosen a former chancellor, home secretary or foreign secretary as its leader. Asked if the party might depart from that tradition, the North East Somerset MP said: 'It's very unlikely, because Sajid has shown so successfully in his relatively brief period as Home Secretary that holding the seals of office means you can get things done, and that gives you an ability to show people what you can really do, and I think that's been so important for him.' Mr Rees-Mogg has positioned himself as the champion of 'clean' Brexit, delivering a stark public warning to Mrs May yesterday that breaking 'red lines' in negotiations could collapse her administration.Theresa May's as opaque as the glass in an old municipal...Share this articleThe intervention by the Old Etonian and investment banker brought a furious response from some ministers who branded him 'insolent' and 'ideological' - although Boris Johnson defended his right to speak out.The North East Somerset MP has become an unlikely hit with grassroots activists for his traditional Conservative views and 'young fogey' style.He currently heads the 60-strong group of Eurosceptic Conservative MPs.However, so-called 'Moggmentum' movement appears to have cooled amid a backlash over the devout Catholic's hardline views on abortion and gay marriage.A source told The Times that PR firms had been approached. 'They were asked to explain how, if Jacob was speaking at a university, they would go about maximising the publicity and harvesting the greatest number of supporters who could later be converted into voting Tory members,' the source said.Veteran Tory MP Sir Bill Cash, a close friend of Mr Rees-Mogg, said he 'didn't recognise' a claim that he had been involved in interviewing PR firms and raising financial backing.           Ministers attacked Mr Rees-Mogg over his Brexit stance yesterday, with Alistair Burt and Sir Alan Duncan among those who accused him of 'lecturing and threatening' the PM          Fellow minister Richard Harrington also waded into the row to condemn Mr Rees-Mogg's comments          Senior Tory MP Sir Nicholas Soames said Mr Rees-Mogg should 'shut up' and accused him of making empty threats - saying he was 'all gong and no dinner' Mr Rees-Mogg has laughed off the idea of becoming leader and insists he is unaware of any fledgling campaign.'I have absolutely no knowledge of this,' he said. Yesterday there were reports that backers of Mr Rees-Mogg had raised a £750,000 war chest in case there is a leadership contest.A pro-Brexit MP has teamed up with a former UKIP member to assemble a fighting fund, according to the Express.A senior Tory said: 'We have given up on Theresa May and the current Cabinet. The membership love Jacob.'

title: How Prince Philip came close landed Britains nuclear test site
story: Newly surfaced documents show the Duke of Edinburgh visited Christmas Island in the South Pacific shortly after Operation Grapple, which saw the UK carry out nuclear weapons tests and hydrogen bomb explosions          Mechanics working on a Douglas Dakota aircraft of the RAF Transport Command on Christmas Island (Kiritimati) in the Central Pacific Ocean, during preparations for the Operation Grapple British nuclear weapons tests at the Island, May 1957      Why Meghan Markle and Kate Middleton can't wear wedges...Prince William 'pledges to make peace in the Middle East his...Share this article'I lost my youngest daughter when she was 13 after she was taken ill aged 11. Her disease has never been disclosed to me, nor have her medical records.' The Ministry of Defence has been contacted for comment.            The designers of the experiment admitted the pilot would have little or no shielding from the radiation from above the waist in comparison to other crew members  Prior to the test, scientists expected the pilot to receive a greater dose of radiation to the head. The crew also war testicular badges which recorded 'significantly lower levels' which 'are of interest and cheer in relation to the possibility of genetic damage'          An RAF serviceman having his hair cut on Christmas Island (Kiritimati) in the Central Pacific Ocean, during preparations for the Operation Grapple British nuclear weapons tests at the Island, May 1957          The documents show that the aircrew were test subjects to assess the effectiveness of experimental radiation dosage measuring equipment          Squadron Leader Eric Denson (pictured) suffered chronic headaches and eventually killed himself in the wake of the Cold War experimentThis year sensational new files were discovered by Shirley Denson, 83, the widow of a pilot who flew in one MoD experiment in 1958.Shirley, who lives in Morden, south London, obtained the papers afters years of research into her husband Eric's service.She believes radiation is the cause of the birth defects like extra teeth in her family. One young relative was recently born with an extra urinary tract.Her husband had suffered such a high dose of radiation to his head he went on to have chronic headaches which led him to kill himself in 1976.Eric and Shirley had already had one daughter together before he was involved in the experiment. She was born healthy.However, 37 per cent of their descendants from children born after Eric passed through the radiation cloud were born with defects or unexplained medical conditions.These included skull deformities, missing or extra teeth and spinal problems.          The MoD continues to deny that Eric and his crew were subjects of an experiment, despite the emergence of new papersTwo of his four children with Shirley were born with abnormalities, as were some of their grandchildren and great-grandchildren.RAF hero Eric was involved in early tests into the radiation caused by atomic and hydrogen bombs.In 1958 he was stationed in the Pacific Ocean on Malden Island and Christmas Island - the site of Operation Grapples, which saw the UK carry out some of its earliest nuclear weapons tests.Eric was ordered to fly his Canberra B6 bomber through a cloud left in the wake of a 2.8 megaton nuclear explosion on April 28, 1958, documents reveal.X-ray badges were stuck to his seat to measure the barrage of radiation as he and two others entered the cloud.They were placed behind his head, on both armrests and by his groin.The documents reveal 'care was taken to ensure as little shielding effect as possible' was given to the X-ray badges. Of course, this meant Eric and his crew became vulnerable to the deadly radiation.The document was an Atomic Weapons Establishment paper looking at ways of testing the badges to make sure they were accurate.They detail the exact amount of radiation absorbed by the head, arms and groin and the bomber's pilot, navigator and wireless operator.They also note the time spent inside the cloud, the height of the plane and the time the bomber entered the cloud after the bomb detonated.The documents goes on to set out the pros and cons of the badges in measuring radiation. They also suggest re-running the experiment with more badges.          One of the documents showed Flight Lieutenant Denson recorded a radiation reading of 13 Roentgens after carrying out the flightWhen Eric's bomber touched down after the test he began to experience vomiting and developed a rash - common symptoms of radiation poisoning.The documents, written by scientists running the experiments, show that Eric, who was 24 at the time, had his head exposed to 65 years' worth of normal ­background ­radiation.This amounted to 17,500 dental X-rays worth of radiation during just six minutes of flight.The badge placed near Eric's groin recorded a dose of 8.8 Roentgens - about 30 years' worth of background radiation.In total he received 18.8Rs, the worst of the three-man crew which flew that day.Shirley is seeking an apology from the Ministry of Defence, who have insisted veterans were not used as guinea pigs during nuclear tests.

title: Corbyns Labour Party breeding softcore Holocaust denial claims leading academic
story: Deborah Lipstadt (file), who rose to prominence in a legal battle with historian David Irving in 2000 after accusing him of Holocast denial, said anti-Semitism was 'embedded' in LabourDr Lipstadt said full-blown Holocaust denial had been 'seriously weakened' with people who promote it widely seen as 'at best loony at worst hateful anti-Semites'.But speaking at the Holocaust Education Trust's annual conference in Westminster, London, said: 'Softcore Holocaust denial is where everything becomes a genocide. 'Softcore Holocaust denial is where people say 'I'm so tired of hearing about this, why am I always hearing about the Holocaust, too much about the Holocaust, oh you Jews and the Holocaust, jokes about the Holocaust…' Downing Street 'bans Donald Trump from meeting Nigel Farage'...'The stakes are higher than we have ever known': PM pleads...Share this articleJeremy Corbyn's (pictured in the Commons last night) Labour is breeding 'softcore' Holocaust denial, Dr Lipstadt warned'But it's more than that - it's a form of anti- Semitism. That's the kind of softcore denial I worry about much more. It's subtly anti-Semitic and its clearly denial because it rewrites history.' A Labour Party spokesperson said: 'Jeremy Corbyn has been absolutely clear that he is a militant opponent of anti-Semitism and is committed to driving it out of politics and our society.'Labour has deep roots in the Jewish community and is campaigning to increase support and confidence in our Party among Jewish people in the UK.'Any complaints of anti-Semitism, including Holocaust denial, are taken extremely seriously and are fully investigated, and appropriate disciplinary action, in line with Party rules and procedures.'Labour's new General Secretary Jennie Formby has made it her first priority to speed up and strengthen our procedures and to develop a programme of political education to create deeper awareness and understanding about all forms of antisemitism.'          She named Ken Livingstone as an example of Labour's problem. The ex-Mayor of London quit the party in May after more than two years of criticism over his rants about Hitler

title: One Britains biggest hoarders vows CLEAN squalid home junk
story: Arthur Watson at his flat which he says he is going to clean up after almost three decades of hoarding          Mr Watson said he is planning on having people round after his daughter marries her boyfriendHe said he now wants to have a few guests around, especially as his daughter Anna gets married to her fiance Matthew, in August.There is currently a mountain of washing up and Arthur's carpet is barely visible beneath the huge piles of newspapers and possessions at the bottom floor flat.  He said: 'I am quite happy, but I have got to the point where I could do with a little tidy up.'My daughter has given up on me. She knows I am a lost cause. She thinks that if I have not poisoned myself by now then I probably never will.          Arthur Watson, 69, has been collecting everything from old newspapers to bicycles for more than 30 years. His small home, which he bought in 1982, is packed in every room with piles of junk          Mr Watson is getting set to tackle the mounds of rubbish and is planning on trips to the dump'I have a few friends around the fish and chip shop, and I have invited them around for barbecue, but never accept my invitations. I think they have heard my house is a bit of a tip.'Arthur, a former museum curator, is not getting rid of everything though and insists some of the items could come in handy one day - including the six children's bicycles he stores away - and says others have sentimental value.He even has the remnants of a handprint his daughter made as a child on his kitchen wall using the goo from a mackerel he was gutting more than a decade ago.Arthur, of Plymouth, Devon, said: 'It is not like I am a miser, I don't have any gold.          A mountain of washing up will need to be tackled by the hoarder who has been hanging onto his stuff for decadesBurglar who killed coin collector by stuffing a sock in his...¿Hoarder¿ dies in a house blaze after firefighters were...Share this article'There is nothing of any value here. In fact if burglars see my flat they think I have already been burgled. I am hoarding memories, and the older you get the more of them I have.'Me and my wife orced more than 20 years ago, and I suppose you could say that was a definite turning point.'She was compulsive with cleanliness, and I had to do all the cleaning, and cooking, everything. It was a bit tricky.'The collecting didn't immediately get worse, but everything I could sweep up I have swept up.'Arthur added that he had kept several things because he thought they might be useful.He said his empty wine bottles are earmarked for blackcurrant wine for example and a portaloo from his camping days makes an emergency toilet.Other items have somewhat odd sentimental value, like the huge stacks of copies of his local newspaper the Plymouth Herald which make the floor uneven.He added: 'My grandfather used to work for the Evening Herald as it was then so I could never throw them out.'          The kitchen is rammed with dirty dishes which Mr Watson says he is going to clear out this coming weekend          Arthur, who started his extreme 'hoarding' after he orced from his wife more than 20 years, revealed he was finally hiring a van and planning several trips to the dump          Some of the items collected by Mr Watson include huge piles of books and newspapers           There is barely room to sit round at Mr Watson's house but he wants to clean his act up to have guests over He insists that he usually finds what he wants amid the mess but confessed his 'retrieval system was not 100 per cent foolproof'.Amidst the chaos there are some items which are relatively neatly stored on shelves and in a filing cabinet and the wedding invite has a special place suspended from a string across the living room.Three years ago he was threatened him with legal action by his local council to tidy up and he cited the Magna Carta in his defence. But he added that no prosecution ever took place.Arthur says he will not call a contract cleaner in case they throw out something valuable amid the piles of papers and dirty dishes.

title: Young couple lost passports flight Greece sent home

We've done everything we could but no one seems to care.Man walks from a burning building with skin hanging off his...Desperate passengers cling on for their lives as ferry...Share this article'It was a nightmare, the biggest you could imagine.'The couple booked their week-long holiday to the five star Atki Hotel on the island of Kos with First Choice and flew out on a TUI jet from Gatwick in June.Lewis, of Portsmouth, who owns his own groundworks company, said: 'It was the first holiday we had together.          The devastated couple were then told they could not enter the country - and within 30 minutes were sent home'We boarded the plane to go to Greece, it was very exciting. We sat to watch a film and chilled out on the plane to pass the time.'They said they put their passports in a transparent plastic bag and tucked them into the seat pockets for the duration of the four-hour flight.But within minutes of stepping off the plane they realised they didn't have the documents and instantly tried to backtrack, but were told they couldn't re-board.Instead a member of staff conducted a search but quickly emerged to say they could not be found.The couple said they pleaded with staff to have another look and gave detailed instructions about where the passports were, but still they could not be found.Kimberley, also from Portsmouth said: 'I realised as soon as we got off the plane, it could only have been two minutes tops.'They told us we couldn't get back on the plane and the made us wait by the door to the airport while someone went to look but they said there was nothing there.'Their surprise turned to horror when they were told they would not be allowed into Greece and would have to return to the UK.Kimberley continued: 'We had people around us making sure we didn't leave.          Lewis and Kimberly were unable to fly back out during the week and had to forfeit the £1,400 holiday. 'We were supposed to be sunning it up in Greece but instead ended up at Stansted,' said Lewis'We were waiting for about 30 minutes for a flight back, we had to wait by the door. They tried to move us somewhere else but I refused.'There were people watching us like we were criminals.'After waiting for between 30 and 40 minutes the couple were put on the next flight back to the UK, and endured another four hour flight.Kimberley added: 'They didn't care, they gave us a boarding pass and chucked us on the next flight, we didn't get a choice - it was disgusting.'The couple have contacted First Choice and TUI but have not managed to locate their passports or had any offer of compensation.A TUI UK spokesperson said: 'We're sorry to hear of Mr Mundy and Ms Floyd's very rare experience on their flight to Greece.'As a result of not having their passports they were not allowed into the country and were flown back to the UK.'After searching the aircraft thoroughly we can confirm their passports were not found.'We would like to remind customers, as we generally do before they leave the aircraft, to ensure they have all their personal possessions with them and to take responsibility of their personal items at all times.'

title: Dolphin swims family coast UK
story: Paul Blackley filmed the stunning moment a dolphin swam up to him while out by Freshwater Bay on the Isle of WightThe photographer said his daughters Emily, 13, and Isobel, 11, had never seen a dolphin before and described it as the 'best day' of their lives.He said: 'I had heard there was a dolphin that had been seen in the water off Freshwater Bay.'So we just positioned ourselves close to where it had been seen surfacing and then let the dolphin decide how close it wanted to get to us.Rare Mercedes that took months to lovingly restore is...Share this article'At times this was very close, as you can see in the video I took, but it was always the dolphin's choice to approach us.'I have surfed with dolphins four or five times and been lucky enough to see them from the shore and from boats 30 to 40 times, but I have never been that close to one before.'It is always amazing to have a close encounter with any wildlife but somehow dolphins are magical to be around.'To be able to share the experience with my girls just made it even more special. My girls had never seen a dolphin before and Isobel kept saying it was the best day of her life.'          Mr Blackley also filmed the dolphin swimming next to his two daughters          The dolphin is then seen ing back underwaterHowever Mr Blackley, who lives on the Isle of Wight, said is he now worried that people may decide to 'harass' the lone dolphine. He said: 'We have been back to see the dolphin in our kayak, but we only stayed out for half an hour as it was obviously trying to feed.'The dolphin came to check us out a couple of times but then went back to trying to catch something to eat.'With any wildlife you always let the wild animal decide how close it wants to be.'There was a boat around the dolphin when we first paddled out and I am concerned about people harassing it.'People shouldn't try to swim with the dolphins and boats should keep at a safe distance and not chase the dolphin.'

title: sabine weiss interview photographer pompidou paris
story: She immortalised street kids and sculptors with an eye to rival Cartier-Bresson. As the Pompidou holds a retrospective, the 93-year-old veteran of street photography praises the power of the instant‘I am coming!” Sabine Weiss shouts as she descends from her studio to greet me. At 93, the Swiss-French photographer is immaculately presented and immediately comes across as a force to be reckoned with – holding court in her Lilliputian home and studio that nestles in a plant-filled courtyard hidden behind a row of 19th-century apartment buildings, in Paris’s wealthy 16th arrondissement.The photographer and her late husband, the American painter Hugh Weiss, built the diminutive structure themselves, gradually converting a disused sculpture workshop measuring 5m x 5m into a place to live and work. This incongruous dwelling – home to Weiss for the last 69 years – proudly endures, much like its inhabitant, despite its perpetually changing backdrop. Hugh found the place in 1949, she says, through a connection in a Montmartre paintshop. “He told me, ‘It has no running water and only an outside toilet – it’s perfect!’” She laughs. “But we were happy. That is the most important thing, no?”Weiss is the last living member of the postwar humanist school of photography that includes such luminaries as Henri Cartier-Bresson, Robert Doisneau, Brassaï and Willy Ronis. Weiss objects to this classification, however, claiming her work is too varied to be reduced to a single historical moment, one that’s synonymous with the mid-century emergence of black-and-white street photography and photojournalism.Born in 1924 in the Swiss-French border town of Saint-Gingolph, Weiss bought her first camera, a cheap Bakelite model, with her pocket money at the age of eight and soon began developing her own film. She knew, before she had even left school, she was going to be a professional photographer. “At the time,” she says, “the idea of being a professional photographer was inconceivable. There were no books, no exhibitions. Maybe there were books in the States for very well-known photographers, but not in Switzerland.”Weiss’s circumstances were somewhat unusual. Her father was a skilled chemical engineer who encouraged his daughter’s aptitude for the technical processes of photography, helping her set up her own dark room in the family home, where she taught herself such techniques as salt-paper and silver-gelatin printing. “My family thought I would be a lab technician,” she says.Weiss completed two lengthy apprenticeships: the first with Studio Boissonnas in Geneva, renowned for its advanced photo processing the second with the German fashion photographer Willy Maywald, after she moved to Paris in 1946. Maywald was a master with lighting, says Weiss. In her three years with him, she learned techniques that would prove critical to her later remarkable versatility as a photographer.The largest exhibition of Weiss’s street photography to date – entitled Les Villes, La Rue, L’Autre – has just opened at the Pompidou Centre in Paris. It consists of images Weiss made mostly for her own enjoyment. “They are my secret garden, my spiritual nest egg, my personal intimate memory.” She never expected to see them in an exhibition, but enjoyed working with the curators. “They have picked some I would not have chosen.”As I sit with Weiss, poring over a lifetime’s work spread out on her coffee table, she has the air of someone who has seen much and regrets little. While many of her mostly male peers pushed their practice as an art form – Cartier-Bresson often insisted he was engaging in drawing or painting by other means – Weiss viewed her image-making as its own craft and embraced the label of photographer.She distinguished herself through sheer range, travelling continuously, photographing for the New York Times, Newsweek, Life, Vogue, Elle, and undertaking commissions for large institutions, notably Nato. But she also did advertising and fashion photography. “My skill, when I began working for myself alone in Paris, was that I already had a lot of experience. I had seven or eight years of photography behind me. When somebody asked me for a picture story – or for advertising, portraits, all kinds of things – I was able to do it.”Unlike Doisneau and Brassaï, Weiss’s street photography and reportage was never staged. “All the pictures I take are entirely instant,” she says. “What I like is to make an instant picture. Even if there are no people, I like the click, click, click. I never wait.”Weiss often had to carry heavy equipment, including multiple cameras, lenses and filters. She also routinely worked with children and animals. “In all these shoots I was alone,” she says. “I was outside in the park looking for babies. I was asking people to make me a glass bubble for one campaign, a wardrobe for another. I had also once to find a suit of armour, all sorts of things. Difficult sometimes, you know?” When I note that she seems equally proud of the photographs she produced for advertising as she is of her street photography, she agrees: “Yes, because sometimes they were very challenging technically.”Weiss has always been ambivalent about being included in exhibitions, viewing print publications as a perfectly suitable showcase. Remarkably, she didn’t even attend her first solo show of 55 photographs at the Art Institute of Chicago in 1954, writing to its curator to say she had too many work commitments in Paris. Nor did she see the celebrated 1955 MoMA exhibition The Family of Man, curated by Edward Steichen, for which the famous photographer travelled to Paris from New York to select three of her photographs.“This was when we still had no running water and I didn’t have a proper darkroom,” says Weiss. She has a simple explanation for her lack of interest in art world recognition: “I didn’t need to have exhibitions. My husband was a painter and he had to show his work. But I was working with all the magazines and they sent me copies, proof that I have done the work. I could see what I have done.”Weiss also concedes that she was too busy to go socialising with her photography peers in Paris and didn’t care to participate in all the mid-century theoretical discussions surrounding photography. These ideas were generated largely by the publication of Brassaï’s Paris at Night in 1933 – to which Henry Miller, Jean-Paul Sartre and other artists and thinkers responded – along with Cartier-Bresson’s The Decisive Moment. In this landmark 1952 publication, Cartier-Bresson outlined his preference for instant photography and dubbed himself “the velvet hand” with “the hawk’s eye”.Perfectly balanced compositions are undoubtedly Weiss’s great strength, but perhaps less well known is her remarkable ability to establish immediate connections with her subjects, no matter how fleeting the encounter. The warmth of her photographs is striking, particularly when compared with the sometimes clinical coldness of Cartier-Bresson’s street photography.Nowhere is Weiss’s ease with people more evident than in her black-and-white shots of children playing in the streets of 1950s Europe and the US. When I ask Weiss to identify her favourite photograph, there is a short pause as she leafs through the pile of contact sheets and prints sitting on the table. She retrieves a black-and-white shot of what looks like a five-year-old boy wearing only a threadbare pair of shorts and pretending to be a horse. The child is staring directly into the camera and is surrounded by his friends, who are looking at him with awe and delight. “I like this picture because he is playing with me,” she says. “He is showing me he is a horse.”Yet Weiss was equally adept at producing classic portraits of celebrated artistic figures, including Samuel Beckett and Joan Miró. She was friends with Alberto Giacometti, having met him in Geneva as a young woman, and photographed the artist, his studio and his work on multiple occasions.She once put a Giacometti sculpture into the back of her car and asked her husband to drive her and their eight-year-old daughter, Marion, to a lake in nearby Bois de Boulogne, where she wanted to photograph the artwork. Weiss placed the sculpture at the edge of the lake and then returned to her camera, put her head beneath the cloth – and suddenly heard a large splash, which terrified her. I expect her to tell me the sculpture had been destroyed, but she laughs and quickly says: “Luckily, it was only Marion. She climbed out of the water covered in tiny little worms!”• Sabine Weiss: Les Villes, La Rue, L’Autre is at the Pompidou Centre, Paris, until 15 October.
