title: children and parents are separated by immigration in the uk
story: "You can't overstate what kind of damage it does," Mr Beales said. Children are frequently reported to experience panic attacks, bed wetting and altered behaviour when a parent is detained.The criticism comes in the wake of family separations in the United States, where images of imprisoned children screaming for the parents has prompted widespread condemnation. In the UK, Home Office regulations state that children are neither split from both their parents nor placed in detention for immigration purposes.But in less than two years Mr Beales says BID has dealt with several cases in which Home Office enforcement has meant children being taken into care.Among them are the four children of Kenneth Oranyendu, who was detained when he reported to the Home Office after dropping them off from school in March.His wife was in Nigeria for her father's funeral at the time, and the 45-year-old begged immigration authorities to allow him to pick his children up from school. But he was referred to an immigration detention centre 200 miles away, and his children placed in care.Within a few days of his arrest Mr Oranyendu's wife was able to return to the UK to collect the children, and the family are now together after he was released on bail.But he still has to report to the Home Office every two weeks, and fears he could be detained again. His children, aged between six and 17 and all British citizens, have been "shattered" by the separation."Every time I go out of the house they are afraid I'm not going to come back," he said. "They are terrified we will abandon them, and suffer from panic attacks. They wake in the middle of the night to check if their mum and dad are still there."Mr Oranyedu has a conviction for drugs smuggling - a crime he denies - and was detained by immigration detention after he served his sentence. His supporters say he is being punished twice because he is not a British citizen. The Home Office told Sky News human rights were "fully considered" Mr Oranyendu's case, and that his status as a "foreign national offender" meant protecting the public and preventing crime were taken into account.Government guidance says children must not be separated from both parents for immigration purposes, and set out that the decision to detain any parent should be "necessary and proportionate" with regard to the children concerned.A spokesperson said immigration procedures would not result in children being taken into care unless in exceptional circumstances, and said children's welfare and safeguarding was at the heart of family returns.

title: facebook gave 61 firms extended access to user data
story: The dating app Hinge, alongside corporations including AOL, Oracle, Nisan, Panasonic and Snap were among those to receive the extended access.Mark Zuckerberg, the social media company's founder and chief executive, previously accepted responsibility for the breach ahead of a Congressional hearing.He said: "We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility, and that was a big mistake. It was my mistake, and I'm sorry."I started Facebook, I run it, and I'm responsible for what happens here."In the UK, MPs have formally requested that Mark Zuckerberg appear in Parliament and answer questions, although he declined.Up to 87 million people were affected by a controversial data breach involving elections consultancy Cambridge Analytica.The disclosures made to Congress also revealed that special privileges had been granted to 52 hardware and software companies.Apple, Amazon, and Huawei are among companies which were allowed to access basic user data to integrate Facebook-related features on their devices and services.Facebook stated that 38 of those 52 arrangements had come to an end, with a spokesperson stating: "The purpose of these partnerships was to build Facebook and Facebook features into the partners' devices and other products.

title: jacob rees mogg steps up
story: NewsJacob Rees-Mogg 'steps up Tory leadership plot' as MPs accused of 'coup' against Theresa MayThe posh MP is jockeying for position with more than half a dozen other Tories looking to take over from Theresa May if the Brexit negotiations implode&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor15:11, 3 JUL 2018NewsThe posh MP is jockeying for position with half a dozen other Tories (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJacob Rees-Mogg’s allies are talking to PR firms as he steps up his leadership campaign, it was claimed today. The posh MP is jockeying for position with more than half a dozen other Tories looking to take over from Theresa May if the Brexit negotiations implode. Supporters of the Old Etonian are reported to have interviewed public relations companies with a view to working on a leadership challenge. Mr Rees-Mogg denied the claim. It comes as a Remain-backing Tory MP warned Brexiteers are plotting a 'coup' against the Prime Minister. A poll of Conservative supporters for the ConHome website has Sajid Javid as favourite to be the next leader, followed by Michael Gove with leading Brexiteer Mr Rees-Mogg in third place. Mr Rees-Mogg, often dubbed the “MP for the 19th Century” because of his old-fashioned style, has been steadily building up his public profile and engaging with 21st Century media.  He recently joined Snapchat, having already opened Twitter and Instagram accounts. The prominent Leave supporter has also appeared on Have I Got News For You, as well as speaking at Conservative Associations as he courts the party’s grassroots. Earlier this week it was said supporters of the millionaire have raised a &pound750,000 war chest if he wants to fight a leadership campaign.  A source familiar with the recent invitation to PR firms told The Times: “They were asked to explain how, if Jacob was speaking at a university, they would go about maximising the publicity and harvesting the greatest number of supporters who could later be converted into voting Tory members.” Insiders said the real reason was to pave the way for tilt at the top job if Mrs May quits or is ousted. Senior Tory backbencher Sir Bill Cash, a close friend of Mr Rees-Mogg, said he “didn’t recognise” a claim he had been involved in interviewing potential PR firms and in raising cash Mr Rees Mogg said he had “absolutely no knowledge” of a bid to sign-up a PR firm.  It comes as the Prime Minister prepares for make-or-break talks with the Cabinet at her country retreat, Chequers, on Friday.  Brexiteers fear they are about to be ambushed with a 'fudge' plan for customs that will keep the UK close to EU rules.  Pro-Remain Chancellor Philip Hammond is set to use the meeting to present new analysis on the costs of Hard Brexit. One bullish Tory MP told the : “We could find the government collapses on Friday night.  If she crosses the Brexit red lines, and it looks like she is going to, then the Brexiteers will withdraw their support for her and Boris, David Davis and the other Brexit ministers will walk.” Another told the newspaper: “Pro-Brexit MPs are ready and willing to pull the trigger. Friday looks as though it could be the day that decides the prime minister’s fate.” Tory MP and former minister Dr Phillip Lee said: There is no doubt that Brexiteers are planning a coup. I call on other rational members of the party to stand against this nonsense. Want to keep up to date with the latest from Westminster? Sign up to our newsletter to receive regular news, expert comment and analysis from our Mirror Politics team.

title: labour reinstates mp jared omara
story: NewsLabour reinstates MP Jared O'Mara after suspension over sexist and homophobic online postsThe party decided to lift his suspension and slap him with a formal warning&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter14:53, 3 JUL 2018NewsJared O'Mara was suspended last October (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour has reinstated MP Jared O'Mara, who was suspended over sexist and homophobic online posts. A disciplinary panel decided the Sheffield Hallam MP, 36, will be given a formal warning. And he will have to attend mandatory training. O'Mara, who defeated former Lib Dem leader Nick Clegg in the 2017 election, had the party whip withdrawn in October, after a string of misogynistic and homophobic online comments were revealed. Mr O’Mara resigned from the Women and Equalities Committee in September and apologised after a string of derogatory comments he made about women and gay men, some from more than a decade ago, when he was in his 20s, were unearthed online.  He was later hit by claims from a constituent who said he called her an ugly bitch in his Sheffield nightclub in March last year. Comments made by O’Mara include referring to gay people as “fudge packers” and “plotters” on a forum dedicated to singer Morrissey. And he apologised for comments which emerged earlier, where he suggested jazz musician Jamie Cullum should be raped to death with his own piano and that he would like to have an orgy with Girls Aloud.

title: mps cheeky england world cup
story: NewsMP's cheeky England World Cup-themed Brexit ad lands him in hot water with the FATonight's clash with Colombia has already sent the nation into World Cup fever. So Labour's Gareth Thomas may have got a tad over-exuberant&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter12:27, 3 JUL 2018Updated12:39, 3 JUL 2018NewsThis ad by MP Gareth Thomas earned him a yellow card from the FA&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTonight's clash with Colombia has already pitched England into World Cup fever. And it seems one MP may have got a tad over-exuberant.  Gareth Thomas earned himself a yellow card from the Football Association after he seized on another Gareth in a tongue-in-cheek Brexit fight.  The Labour MP tweeted an light-hearted image of England manager Gareth Southgate, below the words: Make sure you get your MP to back Gareth this July!. Only in smaller font did he mention he was actually talking about his bid to give people a second Brexit referendum. After what sources described as a stern phone call from a senior FA official in Russia, the image was removed from the MP's Twitter account last night.  Mr Thomas admitted: The image on my Twitter was only meant as a bit of fun to promote my People's Vote Bill this Friday. But the FA weren't happy with it so we took it down immediately. We don't want to tease the FA.  Mr Thomas has a Private Member's Bill before Parliament this Friday, which would force the government to grant a public vote on its withdrawal agreement with the EU. A string of Remain-backing Labour MPs have thrown their weight behind a so-called 'People's Vote'. But it is not Labour policy and the Bill is so far down the Commons 'order paper' that it will not even be debated on Friday. It is likely to be postponed until October 26 but may not be debated then either.

title: theresa may im proud britain
story: NewsopinionTheresa May: I'm determined to end anti-LGBT hatred that still exists in 2018Our LGBT Action Plan sets out the concrete steps to help improve lives for LGBT people and eliminate the discrimination and inequality they face&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTheresa May00:01, 3 JUL 2018Updated13:58, 3 JUL 2018NewsopinionTheresa May has written for the Daily Mirror - and revealed Government plans to ban gay 'cure' therapies (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis summer thousands of people will be celebrating Pride at more than 80 events across the country, from Manchester to London, and Brighton to Aberdeen. There’s lots to celebrate because we can be proud the UK is a world leader in LGBT rights. But I know that, in 2018, many LGBT people still have to deal with discrimination, hatred and even violence and I’m determined to do something about it. Last year we launched the first national LGBT survey which attracted more than 108,000 responses, making it the largest survey of its kind anywhere in the world. Some of the findings make for difficult reading. I was shocked to learn that two-thirds of people avoid holding hands in public with same-sex partners for fear of a negative reaction.  That so many people fear the consequences of this simple gesture shows that a society in which we are all treated equally and fairly is still some way off. Two in five of the people surveyed had experienced verbal harassment or physical violence simply because of their sexuality. Worse still, 90% of those people felt they couldn’t report it because “it happens all the time”. It’s for reasons such as these that we’re publishing our LGBT Action Plan, setting out the concrete steps to help improve lives for LGBT people and eliminate the discrimination and inequality they face. We are going to appoint a national adviser on health inequalities, so the specific needs of LGBT people are at the heart of the NHS. We will continue our investment in programmes to tackle homophobic, biphobic and transphobic bullying in schools, protecting LGBT students and confronting hatred in all its forms.

title: bitching tears bribes bottoms inside
story: NewsBitching, tears, bribes and bottoms - inside Miss Bumbum the backside beauty contest about to go globalMatt Roper was a judge at the Miss Bumbum competition and encountered desperate women prepared to do anything to be crowned champion of Brazil's bizarre beauty pageant&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatt Roper15:21, 3 JUL 2018NewsMatt Roper with some of the entrants in Miss Bum Bum&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWearing sparkly nipple covers and a skimpy sequined thong which leaves nothing to the imagination, the big-thighed woman writhes and gyrates her huge bottom inches away from my face. Then she suddenly drops to the floor, grinding and thrusting as if her life depended on it. Unsure of where to look or how to react, I opt for a contemplative expression, pen in hand - relieved at least that the smoky room and flashing lights are hiding my blushes. Then, when her three minutes are done, she blows over a kiss before gliding off the catwalk - and I look down at the score-sheet in front of me.  Having to mark a woman’s bottom between 0 and 10 makes me feel like the worst kind of person. But as a judge at Brazil’s bizarre Miss Bumbum competition, this is exactly what is expected of me - and as I put pen to paper the hundreds packing the room strain to work out which score I’m awarding her. One of the strangest, yet most fiercely-fought beauty pageants on the planet, in Brazil the annual contest to find the nation’s sexiest bottom is taken deadly seriously. And with the chance to become an overnight superstar at stake, hopefuls famously go to desperate lengths to take the title - from stripping off in public to bribery and even sabotage. Some candidates have been known to sell cars and even houses to finance their campaign for public votes. And now for the first time, butt-proud women all around the globe will be able to compete for an even more illustrious crown - Miss Bumbum World. Organisers said they decided to launch an international version of the contest after being inundated by messages and photos from big-bottomed women around the world begging for a chance to take part. And emotions are expected to reach fever pitch at the star-studded event in Miami in March next year, when Brazil’s national winner will compete against representatives from other countries around the world to find out who has the best butt on the planet. As the only non-Brazilian ever to be a judge on Miss Bumbum, in November last year, I was able to get a unique insight into what the race to next year’s ultimate best bottom award might be like - as well as behind-the-scenes antics and intrigue. As a journalist working in Brazil, I’ve reported on the craziest aspects of the competition - which today makes more headlines around the world than every other beauty pageant put together.  They included one hopeful who strutted naked through a shanty town controlled by gun-wielding gangsters to canvass for votes, another who was caught paying a witch doctor to cast a voodoo spell on a rival, and others who upset the Catholic country’s Christians by recreating the Last Supper scene wearing sexy lingerie at Easter. And no Miss Bumbum season is complete without a fair share of scandals and intrigue. Previous high(low)lights include allegations that one contestant had paid organisers around &pound18,000 for second place others caught using computers to cast thousands of online votes and claims some women had cheated by having butt implants - the competition’s only rule is you can't. The mix of big bums and bizarreness is a recipe for unprecedented media attention. According to organisers, there have been more than 10.3 million articles written about the contest since it first began eight years ago, as well as 48 TV documentaries, including one for the BBC due to be aired in September.  And according to Brazil’s government, only the Rio carnival generates more international news about Brazil than the annual best bottom competition, where winners often go on to become household names at home and abroad. The event is so huge that Miss Bumbum’s creator, Cacau Oliver, now has his own reality show on Brazil’s E! TV channel, called Fame Maker. But nothing could have prepared me for the pressure cooker final of Miss Bumbum in a Sao Paulo bar last November, when the last 15 hopefuls - whittled down from over 2,500 candidates - got their last chance to impress before a panel of judges. Expectation was in the air as hundreds of reporters, photographers and TV cameras packed in to the Noo Bar in the city’s famous Vila Madalena district. As a guest judge I was ushered by security guards into the VIP area, where free food was laid out and I mingled with famous Brazilian stars such as funk DJ Mr Catra and Youtuber Caue Moura. I was one of ten judges - others included TV presenters and reality show stars - invested with the power to send one of the women waiting nervously in the wings to stratospheric heights. As the clocked ticked down to the long-awaited ceremony, excited showbiz reporters rushed to quiz us about our bottom preferences in the hope of gleaming some clue as to which of the 15 finalists might be crowned Queen. But the actual judging process, for such a huge national event, was surprising less rigorous than I had imagined. Each of the judges were giving a sheet with the names of the women, in the order they would appear, first fully dressed in an outfit or costume of their choosing, and second shaking their booty wearing as little as they wanted. For each appearance we were to give a mark between 0 and 10. Most notably, though, it was all about the bumbum. Forget inner beauty, personality, or even a pretty face, we were told, the only thing that mattered was the shape, size, shake and aesthetic of the ass.  By the time the first bottom wiggled on stage, this one belonging to the candidate for Rio de Janeiro, the crowd were in a state of near frenzy. Before each candidate appeared, a video showed her wiggling her bottom on a beach, as the show’s glamorous presenter Gracyanne Barbosa announced their name, age, and ass size. Gracyanne herself, while not being a great presenter, does have a 43-inch wide backside, which appeared to matter more. While some women opted for an evening gown, others were more creative, like the representative of the state of Amazonas, Rosie Oliveira, who strutted the catwalk dressed as an Indian with a huge feather headdress, before unfurling a Brazilian flag with the words “Temer Out!”, a reference to the country’s hugely unpopular president. Some of the other judges squealed excitedly and immediately scribbled ’10’ in her box.  But it was the ‘free dance’ sequence, during which the women returned to the stage to wiggle, thrust and grind their prize asset to the beat of pounding booty music, which brought the crowd to delirium. Excited photographers climbed on top of each other to get the closest shot and each of the contestants made the most of their three minutes to convince us they should be the next Queen of the Brazilian bumbum. One contestant slowly untied her bikini top as she danced provocatively to a slow ballad, another flew onto the stage as Wonder Woman and another strutted down the catwalk dressed as a sexy angel. This time Amazonas’ Rosie was dressed as a sexy jester with harlequin bikini and feathered tickle sticks hanging from her arms. When another wearing the tiniest silver G-string suddenly got on on all fours furiously thrusting her backside to the pounding beat of her chosen funk anthem, the crowd erupted in whistles and applause.  And after each performance, the room fell quiet and all eyes were on me and my fellow judges as we discussed everything from their twerking technique, roundness of their bottom, number of thrusts per second, even the amount of cellulite - before each scribbled down their score. Meanwhile, social media was going into overdrive as Miss Bumbum fans around the country followed the evening’s events, desperately wanting to know who their next bumbum idol would be. Once all the performances were over, the women retired backstage, where many sat nervously biting their nails, or pacing up and down, knowing that one bum wriggle could have made or broken them. On the competition floor, presenters made live broadcasts with their impressions and predictions. It was past midnight when, with all votes counted, the moment finally came for Miss Bumbum found Cacau Oliver to declare the winner. First, an award was made to the candidate who was the least bitchy to the others during the competition, Miss Sympathy, who was voted for by the other women. Then, as the 15 hopefuls lined up on stage, he opened the envelopes containing the name of the runner up, and the winner. And as - unsurprisingly - Rosie Oliveira was declared Brazil’s next Miss Bumbum, there were gasps of surprise and looks of sheer hatred from the other women. The 28-year-old gasped in disbelief and wiped tears from her eyes as the news sunk in, while the remaining 15 women, barely able to hide their disgust, marched off backstage without even stopping to congratulate her. But she didn’t care - suddenly hundreds of photographers were crowded around her, yelling for her to look their way as flashbulbs popped and reporters shouted questions while scribbling in their notepads.

title: alesha mcphail cops record details
story: NewsAlesha MacPhail: Cops record details of ferry passengers on Isle of Bute as family wait to hear if six-year-old's death is suspiciousAlesha MacPhail was staying with her dad and grandma at their home in Rothesay when she went missing yesterday&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMark McGivernSally HindElaine McCahill13:20, 3 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPolice are recording details of all ferry passengers travelling to and from the Isle of Bute as the family of tragic Alesha MacPhail wait to hear if her death is suspicious. The body of the six-year-old was discovered by police in woods on the grounds of a derelict hotel at around 9am yesterday, two and half hours after she was reported missing. Alesha was staying with her dad and gran at their home in Rothesay, Isle of Bute, when the alarm was raised. Her mother Georgina Genie Lochrane, 23, found out the heartbreaking news about her daughter after Alesha's grandmother posted an appeal on Facebook .  Genie has since been escorted by police from her home and taken to the island yesterday afternoon. Police have confirmed the body found is that of the six-year-old and a post mortem is being carried out this afternoon.  As police continue their investigation, they are recording the details of every ferry passenger travelling to and from the island, the Daily Record reports. Alesha's relatives from Coatbridge said they are shocked by the tragedy. Alan McGuire confirmed that the youngster was visiting her gran on Bute when the tragedy happened. Alan said: “Alesha would go to Bute quite often to visit her gran and this was just a regular visit.  “We are devastated about what has happened because she was a lovely wee girl. “At the moment we simply don’t know what is happening. We are waiting to hear if the police are treating it as suspicious or as a tragic accident.” His partner Lisamarie said: “I don’t want to say too much because we don’t know many facts. She was a lovely girl and this has been a shock.” Another relative said: “The family have had a lot of heartbreak in recent years but this is unbearable. “The police are investigating and at this stage we don’t know if this is an accident or something even worse.” Alesha was a pupil at Chapelside Primary School in Airdrie, North Lanarkshire and head teacher Wendy Davie paid tribute to her this morning.  She said: Alesha started with us at Chapelside Primary in August 2016 and had just finished primary two. She loved being at school and enjoyed all aspects of literacy, in particular writing. She was such a perfectionist in her handwriting and was very proud of her work. Alesha was very friendly and she welcomed everyone first thing in the morning at breakfast club. She was a very considerate child who loved being part of a group and she was popular with all the other children, and was a smiley and happy young girl. She was part of the family of Chapelside Primary and she will be greatly missed by everyone at the school. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family, friends and Chapelside Primary community at this very sad time. The area surrounding Alesha’s gran’s home, around half a mile from the spot where her body was found, was sealed off by police tape, with an officer standing guard at the cordon. The scene itself where Alesha’s body was discovered was concealed by thick foliage. A small clearing in the shrubs, which appeared to be an entrance to the grounds of the former hotel, was also taped off. Detective Superintendent Stuart Houston from Police Scotland’s Major Investigation Teams said: “This death of a 6 year old child has shocked the tight knit community of Rothesay and it is imperative that we find out what has happened.

title: coastguard pleads sunseekers not bring
story: NewsCoastguard pleads with sunseekers not to bring giant novelty floats to beach after 15 people rescued in one dayCoastguards said an increasing number of people are being swept out to see on the novelty floats&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill13:40, 3 JUL 2018Updated13:42, 3 JUL 2018NewsThe Coastguard has warned beach goers not to bring inflatable floats to the beach (Image: Hillhead Coastguard Rescue Team)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe country's beaches are jam packed thanks to the current heatwave but coastguards are pleading with sun-seekers not to use giant inflatables after 15 people were injured in one day. Coastguards have warned swimmers against the use of the novelty floats after an increasing number were washed out by the tide. It comes after 15 people straddling giant unicorns and pink flamingos had to be rescued from along the south coast on Monday. In total, officials received 18 calls about people in trouble on the blow-up devices. The current heatwave, which has seen daytime temperatures hovering around 30C, has seen beaches packed and people staying in the sea longer.  Coastguards are advising the public that inflatable toys are not designed for coastal waters where they are quickly swept out to sea by winds and currents. One swimmer lounging on an inflatable unicorn got into trouble at Hayling Island in Portsmouth, Hants, meaning the Hayling Coastguard Rescue Team and RNLI lifeboats had to be launched. HM Coastguard search and rescue helicopter from Lee-on-Solent was also scrambled to look for the embarrassed day-tripper. Another man with an inflatable dinghy in the same area was also reported to be in difficulties, as were other people on a large, pink blow-up flamingo. In a tweet the Maritime and Coastguard agency urged people to leave inflatables at home, saying they should not be used in the sea.  They posted: “More than 15 people have had to be rescued this evening along the south coast. Common denominator? They were all using inflatables. Please leave them at home - they're NOT for the sea. #999.” HM Coastguard duty controller Piers Stanbury said: “We’ve had people rescued from a number of beaches along Hampshire and Sussex coastline. “Each one of them had been using an inflatable. Thankfully, everyone so far has been rescued and is safe. “We’ve had to waste RNLI and Coastguard volunteers’ time to ensure that abandoned inflatables did not have anyone at risk associated with them. “We can’t stress enough that these inflatables are not suitable for use in the sea. “Tide conditions, the wind, any changes in the weather can just take them out beyond safe depths. Please, don’t use them, don’t take them to the seaside.

title: history behind prince louis christening
story: NewsHistory behind Prince Louis' christening gown and the 177-year-old Victorian designRoyal baby's christening is set to take place on July 9, a little over two months after he was born on April 23&nbspShareByAndrew SnellHomepage Editor14:30, 3 JUL 2018Updated14:41, 3 JUL 2018NewsWilliam wears the original gown at his christening in 1982 (Image: PA Archive)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Louis will be christened this month , and he'll be wearing a very special gown for the occasion. The service is set to take place on July 9, a little over two months since he was born on April 23. And he is set to follow scores of royals before him by wearing the family's formal christening gown on the big day. Louis will wear a replica of the silk and lace christening gown worn by royal babies since 1841. The original was commissioned by Queen Victoria for her daughter Victoria, and made by Scottish dressmaker Janet Sutherland.  It was based on Queen Victoria's own wedding dress, and was made of Spitalfields silk and Honiton lace. The original was worn by 62 royal babies, including then-Princess Elizabeth - now the Queen - for her christening at Buckingham Palace in 1926. But after the christening of Prince Edward's daughter Louise in 2004 it was decided that the original gown was too delicate to be worn.

title: how long heatwave last glorious
story: NewsHow long will the heatwave last? Hot weather set to stick aroundThe glorious heat in Britain, which is currently warmer than Barbados, is forecast to remain through the second half of July and August&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlistair Grant22:39, 2 JUL 2018Updated10:10, 3 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe glorious sunshine that's been basking Britain in recent weeks shows no sign of going anywhere, according to forecasters. The Met Office has forecast highs up to 33C this week and 35C next week - after eight days in a row already at between 29C and 33C. And the heat is forecast to remain through the second half of July and August, computer models show. Britain is hotter than 29C Barbados. The famous 1976 summer saw standpipes on the street as Britain sweltered. The heatwave has left Brits feeling uncomfortably hot with many people saying they have struggled to sleep.  Why is it so hot? High pressure over the UK is causing high levels of sunshine and clear skies. Unlike our usual hot spells that are down to warm air pushing in from the continent, this heatwave is caused by the weather lifting the temperature day on day.    How long will the UK heatwave last? Forecasters say the uncomfortable, sweaty nights show no sign of disappearing. Met Office forecaster Helen Roberts said: “There’s no sign of an end to the heat. Warmth looks like continuing for the first half of July. And forecast models point to above-average temperatures for much of July and August.” What areas will it affect? Thursday looks like the peak of this week's heat, with the hottest areas in the west, while the eastern coast getting fresher weather.  Highs of 30C are expected on Thursday, with the North West getting a high of 31C.  Northern Scotland may get cooler by Thursday, while the South and West of England will remain hot through to the weekend.    When will it rain? The Met Office has issued a weather warning for thunderstorms - the first such advisory since the service was introduced. Helen Roberts added: “This week could see 33C in the second half of the week, and next week looks much like last week and could come close to 35C. “Lots of very warm, dry, sunny and settled weather is ahead, and humid nights mean it will be difficult to sleep.”  When was it last this hot? The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “Parallels with the famous 1976 summer can be made. Ex-BBC and Met Office forecaster John Hammond of weather trending said: “Hot and dry weather breeds hot and dry weather. This effect was seen in 1976. This spell ending seems increasingly unlikely through the first half of July.” Metweather forecaster Jo Farrow Paul Michael White said: “The storms are no breakdown as the heatwave will keep on cooking.”

title: parents trial after doctors found
story: NewsParents on trial after doctors found newborn baby suffered head injuries and bruised genitals before his deathMarina Smyth, 21, and Michael Osborne, 22, deny causing or allowing serious physical harm to Bailey Smyth-Osborne&nbspShareByJulia Roberts12:05, 3 JUL 2018NewsMarina Smyth, 21, and Michael Osborne, 22, deny causing or allowing serious physical harm to their son Bailey Smyth-Osborne who was found to have suffered head injuries and bruising to his genitals before his death&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA newborn baby suffered head injuries, a bruised penis and a fractured leg before his death from pneumonia and sepsis, a court heard. Bailey Smyth-Osborne was said to have been subjected to 'more than one' blunt impact of mild to moderate force, as well as a yanking and twisting motion to his left limb. His penis may also have been pinched, and any trauma he suffered went beyond rough-handling, a jury was told. It is alleged one of his parents, Marina Smyth or Michael Osborne, caused the injuries while the other was aware and failed to protect him. Bailey was just three weeks old when the young couple found him stiff, cold and not breathing in his Moses basket next to their bed at their flat in Tonbridge, Kent, on December 5, 2016.  Despite desperate resuscitation attempts by both Osborne and paramedics, Bailey could not be revived. But a court heard that although cause of death was later recorded as a result of pneumonia, sepsis and a cold-like virus, other injuries were discovered by doctors which caused concern. These included a 5cm long bruise to the right-hand side of his head, bruising and swelling to his penis, and bruising across the middle joints of three of his fingers. Bailey also had bruises to his thumb, left elbow, left ankle and right heel, and 'quite intense' bleeding under his scalp. Prosecutor Jennifer Knight told Maidstone Crown Court in Kent on Monday: The head injuries found are consistent with more than one blunt impact of mild to moderate force. Any bruising to a young baby who is not yet mobile, without explanation is a cause of concern, particularly bruising to the penis which raises the possibility of pinching or impact.  Bailey's 'severe' fractured left tibia was discovered during a CT scan and resulted from 'forcible traction' most likely occurring 24 to 48 hours before he died, added Miss Knight. The kind of fracture caused by pulling with a twisting motion, a twist or yanking, injury...a very distinctive kind of fracture typically seen in non-accidental injury, she explained. Both the bruising and fracturing indicated a level of trauma beyond rough handling of Bailey and in-keeping with physical assault of Bailey in the period leading up to death. Smyth, 21, of Oxford Gardens, Maidstone, and Osborne, 22, of Bybrook Road, Kennington, Ashford, Kent, deny causing or allowing serious physical harm to a child between November 16 and December 6, 2016. The jury of seven women and five men was told the prosecution does not have to prove which parent inflicted the injuries. But Miss Knight said whichever defendant was not responsible would have still been aware of the significant risk posed to their child. It is the Crown's case that one of these two defendants was responsible for Bailey's injuries and the other, though not the actual perpetrator, allowed them to occur by failing to take responsible steps to protect Bailey from a risk of injury which should have been foreseen, she added. The court heard Osborne and Smyth met as teenagers. They lived together in Walters Farm Road and Bailey was born healthy and without complications on November 16, 2016.  He was discharged with his mum that same day and other than being diagnosed with oral thrush at two weeks' old, for which he was prescribed drops and then gel, was well. Bailey was also described as appearing 'well and content' at a family birthday party on December 3, just two days before he died. The court heard the couple would take it in turns to care for their son during the night and he had last been fed by Smyth at 12.30am on December 5. A neighbour later told police that he had heard a baby crying at about 1am. Jacob Nash said he went to his balcony window to listen and could hear a high-pitched cry that he thought was unusual and lasted quite a long time, maybe 20 to 25 minutes, said Miss Knight. But Smyth told police she had not heard any crying and it was not until she woke at 10am that she discovered her son was unresponsive. Having handed him to Osborne, she then telephoned her mum, crying and saying Bailey was not breathing. But it was another 45 minutes before Smyth dialled 999, the court heard. When an emergency first responder arrived just four minutes later he noticed Bailey was unconscious, grey in colour, with a stiff chest and jaw, and arms and legs which were cool to the touch. Osborne was giving him CPR under the instruction of the ambulance control centre operator. Paramedics took over but the court was told by 11am it was decided the newborn had been dead 'for some time' and any further attempts to resuscitate him would be futile. However, having been taken to Pembury Hospital, doctors immediately noticed bruising to his head and penis, the court heard.  His further injuries were then discovered during a post-mortem examination. Smyth and Osborne were arrested and twice interviewed by police. Both denied either being responsible for, or aware of, their son's injuries. Marina Smyth had no explanation for them. She could think of no occasion where she or Michael Osborne had ever handled Bailey in a way that might have caused his leg injury, said Miss Knight. She said he always cried when he was undressed or had his nappy changed but she had not noticed any crying that was unusual. Marina Smyth said she did not remember seeing any bruising to Bailey's penis and could not think of any reason why he would have bruising to his fingers, the head or the impacts to the top of his head. Smyth said she had fed and put her baby to sleep in his Moses basket, and did not notice any crying during the night. She then found Bailey unresponsive the next morning, gave him to Osborne and dialled 999. Asked about her relationship with Osborne, Smyth told police he would get 'stressed out' and described a couple of occasions when he woke her during the night because he was agitated and struggling to get their son back to sleep.

title: schoolgirl unable talk anyone dad
story: NewsSchoolgirl unable to talk to anyone but her dad for seven years is cured of 'mutism' after 'miracle' holidayDad Fin Wallace says little Katie is like a different child and has finally been able to speak to her sister and school friends&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmma CramptonAmber Hicks10:50, 3 JUL 2018NewsKatie Wallace with her dad Fin Wallace (Image: SWNS - Leeds SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolgirl who spent seven years suffering in silence unable to speak to anyone but her dad has been 'cured' thanks to a 'miracle' holiday. Little Katie Wallace has for the first time been able to speak to her sister and school friends - and she owes it to a trip abroad. The eight-year-old's crippling anxiety and selective mutism meant she would clam up around others, but she has always been able to speak to her dad. However, a once in a lifetime charity trip to Tenerife in May this year left Katie so excited and carefree she was soon chatting and getting involved with others. Katie and her dad Fin went on the incredible holiday thanks to money raised by local Lancashire charity, Days of Sunshine.  The charity takes local children away throughout the year and believed Katie - who had never been out of the country before - would really benefit from a fun trip in the sunshine. Speaking of Katie’s incredible progress single dad Fin, 52, said: “She’s a different child, I can’t believe it. “When I say she was silent, she was completely mute for seven years. “I can’t believe how much of a difference the holiday has made. I can’t pinpoint exactly what made the difference I think it was a mixture of everything. “A new place, amazing activities and new friends that she felt comfortable with, I don’t even think she realised she’d started to interact.  “She was just too excited and loving life, it was incredible to see. “It’s quite a journey we have been on and it feels like this has been a miracle holiday.” Katie was diagnosed with selective mutism - a severe anxiety disorder - when she was just four years old leaving her unable to speak to anyone except her dad. Miraculously she is now able to speak to her teacher, albeit not in front of the class, and she is able to chat with school pals and her big sister Emma Wallace, 28. Fin, from St Annes, Lancs., believes a lot of Katie’s anxieties are down to her early childhood before he took over her full-time care when she was two.  He said: “She’s already been through so much, she's such a delicate little thing and I just want the best for her. “I can’t begin to tell you how awful it was, she would suffer in silence if I wasn’t around not telling anyone if she felt poorly or was in pain. “She didn’t show expressions either, a clown could run into the classroom and she would not flinch.” Finn was starting to feel helpless and was worried Katie would continue to suffer from her selective muteness for the rest of her life. He said: “No one knew how to help, the school did their best but all you know is what you read on the internet. “She had a speech therapist but I didn’t think that would help as her speech itself is fine, she is very articulate when she talks to me.”  Fin, who is unemployed after having a heart attack and being diagnosed with cancer in 2015, said it was distressing for Katie when he was in the hospital. He said: “I was in the hospital for two weeks and Katie had to stay with her big sister Emma while I was recovering. “I can’t even begin to imagine how scared she must have been as it was the first time we had been apart and she knew I wasn’t very well. “She must have felt so lonely not speaking to anyone for so long. “It is incredible the change in her in the last month, I am so grateful to the charity - they have changed our lives beyond words.

title: shocking moment hooded thief snatches
story: NewsShocking moment hooded thief snatches thousands of pounds from Ladbrokes employee on way to lodge moneyThe 18-year-old was left shaken by the terrifying ordeal&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTim Baker11:42, 3 JUL 2018Updated11:56, 3 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis shocking footage shows a hooded thief robbing thousands of pounds from a Ladbrokes employee. The 18-year-old woman was on her way to lodge the bookie's earnings in the Post Office when she was set upon by the thug. Dash-cam footage captured by a passing driver shows a man in a white hoodie snatching the money before fleeing the scene. The video was released by Hertfordshire Police on Monday as they appealed for information on the theft that took place in Hatfield, Herts. Police are also appealing for information about a second man who threatened the teenager before they made off with the shop's takings.  The motorist who filmed the ordeal comforted the victim before taking her back to the Ladbrokes. Detective Constable Andrew Greenman said: We are grateful to the member of the public who has shared their footage with us after being in the right place at the right time. We are following several lines of inquiry at this stage, one of which is appealing to the public to ask if they recognise the man pictured. I want to reassure the victim that we are doing all we can to capture those responsible.  A spokesman for Hertfordshire Police said: Officers investigating a robbery in Hatfield have released dash cam footage of the offence in progress, as well as still images, in order to identify the two suspects. It happened in Wellfield Road, Hatfield, at 2.10pm on June 25. The victim, an 18-year-old woman, works at Ladbrokes in Birchwood and had left the branch with a large quantity of the store's cash takings in a bag, with the intention of banking it at a Post Office in the town centre.

title: universitys refugee scheme comes under
story: NewsUniversity's refugee scheme comes under fire - and they have the perfect response for the hatersA university is being applauded on social media for giving an incredibly sassy response to critics of their new scholarship scheme&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin13:46, 3 JUL 2018News (Image: Get Reading)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe admissions department at the University of Reading might need to gird their loins, as thousands of people are currently taking an interest in the establishment. That's because its Twitter account is dishing out some serious sass. On Monday evening (July 2), the university's Twitter posted a statement regarding negative feedback for their new refugee scholarship scheme. And people can't deal with their response. Instead of shaking it off like Taylor Swift would, the university clapped back at haters of their plans, telling them to 'jog on'.  They wrote: We've had feedback over the last week that some people are unhappy with our plan to offer up to 14 scholarships to refugees living in the local area. To these people, we would like to say: Tough. Jog on. Thousands of people have liked and shared the tweet, with many taking time to praise whoever runs the account. One person said: Amazing. Promote whoever is in charge of your social media.  Another wrote: James Blunt has a new rival for king/queen of Twitter. A third added: I'm in love with you right now Reading. Plans for the University's refugee scholarship scheme were revealed back in June. The scheme has been developed as part of a partnership with Reading Refugee Support Group and Reading University Students' Union.   According to the University's website the scheme will include:   Up to five scholarships covering tuition fees for pre-sessional English 11-week programmes. Up to two each for Foundation, Undergraduate and Post-Graduate taught study that make up the difference between the already available financial support through Student Finance Authorities (SFA) and what the university advises students as the reasonable cost of studying in Reading. One each for Foundation, Undergraduate and Post-Graduate taught study covering the full tuition and maintenance costs for refugee students who were not eligible for funding through SFA.

title: who prince louis godparents likely
story: NewsWho Prince Louis' godparents are likely to be - and why it won't be Meghan MarkleDuke and Duchess of Cambridge have kept quiet on who they are going to name as godparents&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAndrew SnellHomepage Editor11:31, 3 JUL 2018Updated13:26, 3 JUL 2018NewsPrince Louis of Cambridge (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The christening of Prince Louis is just around the corner, and there's already speculating about who will be involved in the ceremony.  The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have kept quiet on who they are going to name as godparents for their youngest child. But bookies are backing close confidants, like the couple's outgoing private secretaries Miguel Head and Rebecca Priestley, rather than family members. Alex Apati of Ladbrokes said: It's looking increasingly likely the Duke and Duchess will turn to trusted aides over family members.  Here are the latest odds on who could be Prince Louis ' godparents...   Favourite to be named as godfather is Miguel Head, Prince William's outgoing private secretary. He has been with the Royal Family for more than ten years, and took over as private secretary for the Duke in 2013.  He is due to leave his role this month, and will be replaced by Simon Case, a top civil servant in the government's Brexit department.  Tiggy Legge-Bourke - 2/1  Tiggy Legge-Bourke was William and Harry's nanny, and helped them through the death of their mother Princess Diana in 1997. She left royal service in 1999, but has remained close to the two princes. William is reportedly the godfather to her son, Tom.   Laura Lopes is the daughter of William's stepmother Camilla, from her first marriage to Andrew Parker-Bowles.  Her 10-year-old daughter Eliza was one of Kate's bridesmaids when she married William in 2011. Rebecca Priestley - 4/1  As well as William's top aide Miguel Head, Kate's former private secretary Rebecca Priestley is a favourite to be made godparent. The duchess' aide was with her since 2013, and was on hand to help Kate out during the first six years of her marriage. But she stepped down from the role last year, and is now director of a consultancy firm. David Jardine-Paterson - 5/1  David Jardine-Paterson went to Eton at the same time as Prince William, and later married one of his friends. His wife, Emilia Jardine-Paterson, is god-mother to Prince George. His younger brother, JJ Jardine-Paterson, dated Kate's sister Pippa for four years.  Hugh van Cutsem jr is the son of Prince Charles' best friend from school. The four van Cutsem brothers have been close to William and Harry since childhood. Hugh's 11-year-old daughter Grace van Cutsem is Prince William's god-daughter, and was a bridesmaid at the Duke and Duchess' wedding. She became famous after being pictured with her hands over her ears when the newlyweds appeared on the Buckingham Palace balcony. Other favourites  The older sisters of William's mum Princess Diana - Lady Jane Fellowes and Lady Sarah McQuodale - both have odds of 6/1. Captain Mark Dyer, a close family friend often said to be a second father-figure to Prince William, has odds of 6/1. Meanwhile William's cousins Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie both have odds of 7/1. Who didn't make the top of the list   Prince Harry's new wife Meghan Markle is way down the list of favourites, at 14/1.  Although the new Duchess of Sussex is close to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridgem it's not seen as likely that she'll be made a godparent. This is because the royals still follow a pattern of choosing close friends and even former members of staff, and Meghan falls outside that category.  The same goes for Louis' uncle Prince Harry and his auntie Pippa Middleton , who at 10/1 are both a bit of a long-shot. Kate and Pippa's brother James Middleton is also in at 10/1.  And for those interested, Donald Trump has odds of 1000/1.   Prince George has seven godparents, including Earl Grosvenor - one of the wealthiest men in the country.   He also has fellow-royal Zara Tindall , Prince William's cousin, and Jamie Lowther-Pinkerton , William's former private secretary.   His other godparents are William and Kate's pals Oliver Baker , William van Cutsem and Emilia Jardine-Paterson , as well as a friend of Princess Diana, Julia Samuel .  Who were Princess Charlotte's godparents?

title: young couple sent home first
story: NewsCouple sent home from first foreign holiday within 30 minutes of landing after passports 'lost' on planeLewis Mundy and Kimberley Floyd were left devastated when their dream trip was scrapped&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJohn Bett11:10, 3 JUL 2018Updated11:16, 3 JUL 2018NewsLewis and Kimberley described it as the biggest nightmare you could imagine (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young couple on their first foreign holiday together were sent home within 30 minutes of landing - after their passports were 'lost' on the plane. Lewis Mundy and Kimberley Floyd, both 27, excitedly boarded a TUI flight to Greece and tucked their passports into the magazine pocket of their seats. But after stepping off the jet they realised they did not have the documents. They instantly tried to backtrack, but were told they couldn't re-board. Instead a member of staff conducted a search but quickly emerged to say they could not be found. The couple pleaded with airline employees to have another look and gave detailed instructions about where the passports were, but still they could not be found.  They were then refused entry the country and were sent packing on a return flight to the UK within 30 minutes. Lewis and Kimberly, both from Portsmouth, were unable to fly back out on another date and had to forfeit the &pound1,400 holiday. Lewis, who owns his own groundworks company, described it as the biggest nightmare you could imagine. He said: We boarded the plane to go to Greece, it was very exciting. We sat to watch a film and chilled out on the plane to pass the time. We were supposed to be sunning it up in Greece but instead ended up at Stansted. There's no sign of our passports and we've had no help, no compensation, nothing. We've done everything we could but no one seems to care. It was a nightmare, the biggest you could imagine.  The couple booked their week-long holiday to the five star Atki Hotel on the island of Kos with First Choice and flew out on a TUI jet from Gatwick in June. Kimberley told how people looked at them like they were criminals as they waited. She said: I realised as soon as we got off the plane, it could only have been two minutes tops. They told us we couldn't get back on the plane and the made us wait by the door to the airport while someone went to look but they said there was nothing there.  We had people around us making sure we didn't leave. We were waiting for about 30 minutes for a flight back, we had to wait by the door. They tried to move us somewhere else but I refused. There was people watching us like we were criminals. After waiting for between 30 and 40 minutes the couple were put on the next flight back to the UK, and endured another four hour flight. Kimberley added: They didn't care, they gave us a boarding pass and chucked us on the next flight, we didn't get a choice - it was disgusting.
